questions.text: Which of the following factors is responsible for increasing gastric motility?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of fatty food in the stomach

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of tryptophan in the stomach

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of acid in the stomach

questions.explanation:
Factor

Effect on Gastric Motility

Explanation

Distension of the stomach

Increases gastric motility

Stretching of the stomach wall activates mechanoreceptors, stimulating motility.

Gastrin

Increases gastric motility

Hormone released in response to food, especially proteins, that stimulates gastric motility.

Acetylcholine (ACh)

Increases gastric motility

Released by the parasympathetic nervous system, promoting smooth muscle contraction.

Peptides and amino acids

Increases gastric motility

Presence of partially digested proteins or amino acids triggers gastrin release.

Gastric emptying reflex

Increases gastric motility

Reflex activated when food enters the duodenum, regulating the rate of gastric emptying.

Increased secretion of digestive enzymes

Increases gastric motility

The release of gastric juices and digestive enzymes aids in the mixing and movement of food.

questions.text: A child accidentally took a bottle full of iron tablets. Which of the drugs is used as an antidote for iron poisoning?

E

Chelator

Uses

Other Information

Deferoxamine
  • Acute iron poisoning
  • Transfusion siderosis
  • Given parenterally.
  • Not preferred in chronic iron overload (Deferiprone is preferred)

Deferiprone

questions.text: Adrenaline acting via beta 2 receptors causes bronchodilation, whereas histamine acts through H1 receptors to cause bronchoconstriction. Which type of antagonism is it?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Physiological antagonism

Explanation:

Type of Antagonist

Description

Example

Physiological Antagonist

Involves two agents that produce opposite effects on the same physiological function without interacting directly with each other or the same receptor.

Histamine causes bronchoconstriction, while adrenaline causes bronchodilatation

Chemical Antagonist

(Option B)

Direct interaction between two drugs to form an inactive product.
  • Heparin works by enhancing the activity of antithrombin III, which inhibits blood clotting.
  • Protamine sulfate binds to the negatively charged heparin, neutralizing its anticoagulant effect.

Non-Competitive Antagonist

(Option C)
  • Prevents the action of an agonist without competing with it for the binding site.
  • Irreversible binding to the receptor reduces the maximum effect of the agonist.

Phenoxybenzamine binds to α-adrenergic receptors, reducing the effect of adrenaline.

Competitive Antagonist

(Option D)
  • Competes with agonists for the same binding site, reducing the potency of the agonist.
  • Reversible binding to the same receptor site as the agonist.

Propranolol (β-blocker) binds to β-adrenergic receptors, reducing the effect of adrenaline.

questions.text: In the management of diabetes mellitus, lactic acidosis is caused by which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Metformin

Metformin

MOA
  • Stimulates the AMP-dependent protein kinase (AMPK) in the presence of insulin.
  • It inhibits hepatic gluconeogenesis, fatty acid oxidation, and non-oxidative glucose metabolism and increases insulin sensitivity.
  • Inhibits the mitochondrial glycerol phosphate dehydrogenase
  • Reduces peripheral resistance to insulin in muscle and adipose tissues

Dose

500 mg OD to 2550 mg/day (max)

Uses

First-line oral hypoglycemic for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

DOC: Prophylaxis in prediabetes or impaired glucose tolerance

Metabolic syndrome

DOC: Diabetes due to insulin resistance

  • In PCOS: Metformin also promotes ovulation
  • Clozapine-induced DM/glucose intolerance.
  • Cushing syndrome
  • Gestational diabetes

Other benefits

  • Weight loss in obese patients and weight neutrality in thin patients.
  • There is no risk of hypoglycemia (No effect during the normoglycemic state).
  • Reduction of lipogenesis (decrease triglyceride and LDL levels).
  • Decreases micro- and macrovascular complications of DM
    • Micro: diabetic neuropathy, nephropathy, retinopathy
    • Macro: MI and stroke

Side effects
  • Nausea/Vomiting/Diarrhoea
  • Megaloblastic anaemia: reduces vitamin B12 absorption from GIT
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Avoid metformin in Renal disorder, liver disease, COPD, CHF, dehydration, and sepsis (hypoxia increases lactic acid production).

Metformin

MOA

Activates AMP-dependent protein kinase (AMPK), inhibiting hepatic gluconeogenesis and fatty acid oxidation while increasing insulin sensitivity.

Dose

500 mg OD to 2550 mg/day

Uses
  • First-line treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
  • Prophylaxis in prediabetes or impaired glucose tolerance.
  • Management of metabolic syndrome and PCOS (promotes ovulation).

Other benefits

  • Weight loss in obese patients and weight neutrality in thin patients
  • No risk of hypoglycemia, and it leads to a reduction of lipogenesis
  • Decreases micro- and macrovascular complications of DM

Side effects
  • Common: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea.
  • Rare but serious: Lactic acidosis
  • Reduces vitamin B12 absorption, causing megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: Beta-blockers are ideally avoided in which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Diabetes mellitus with hypertension

Uses of beta-blockers

Drug of choice
  • Migraine prophylaxis (Option D)
  • Essential tremors (Option A)
  • Aortic dissection if they also have hypertension

Other Uses
  • Hypertension-second-line drugs
  • Stable angina: Decrease the frequency of attacks and increase exercise tolerance. (Option C)
  • Cardiac arrhythmias: Used in both supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias.
  • Congestive heart failure: Decreases mortality.
  • Thyrotoxicosis: Propranolol controls the sympathetic symptoms
  • Glaucoma: Timolol and Betaxolol are used.
  • Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Improves cardiac output).
  • Myocardial infarction (Ml): Secondary prophylaxis of Ml and myocardial salvage during evolution of Ml (decreases mortality).

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 65-year-old woman who arrives at the outpatient department with symptoms of breathlessness and fatigue? She has no previous medical history of reactive airway disease or heart disease, but she has undergone breast cancer treatment including breast conservation surgery and chemoradiation. On examination, engorged neck veins and jugular venous pressure (JVP) indicate a rapid x and y descent. The chest x-ray findings are as follows.
Proton pump inhibitor suppresses gastric acid secretion by acting on?
questions.explanation:
Proton pump inhibitor

MOA

It inhibits the H+/K+ ATPase pump located in the parietal cells of the stomach, thus reducing acid secretion in the stomach.

Potency of PPI
  • Rabeprazole > Lansoprazole > Rabeprazole > Omeprazole > Pantoprazole
  • All PPIs have equal efficacy.

Properties

  • Acid production reduction persists for 2 to 4 days even after stopping the drug and resumes later.
  • Duration of action is typically 2 to 4 days.
    • Omeprazole is the fastest acting PPI.
    • PPIs are acid labile; Enteric coating can protect from acid degradation.
    • They should be taken on an empty stomach when only ~I0% of proton pumps are active, followed 1 hour later by a meal to activate the H+/K+/ATPase at a time when plasma concentration of the PPI is maximal.

Side effects

  • Chronic use of PPIs can lead to hypergastrinemia, which can further result in:
    • ECL hyperplasia
    • Fundic gland polyposis
    • Atrophic gastritis
  • Gastrointestinal upset (nausea, constipation, diarrhoea)
  • Increased microbial growth leads to a higher risk of bacterial infection
  • Increased risk of bone fractures due to hypocalcemia (reduced absorption of calcium)

questions.text: What can be done to address the concerns of a woman who is 3 months postpartum, regularly breastfeeding, and experiencing amenorrhea for the past 3 months, before considering surgery?
Which of the following agents is not used in the management of bronchial asthma?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Cholinergic drugs

Explanation:

Drugs used in asthma

Category

Examples

MOA

Uses

Short-acting beta-agonists (SABAs)

(Option C)

Albuterol (Salbutamol), Levalbuterol

Stimulates beta-2 adrenergic receptors, causing bronchial smooth muscle relaxation.

Acute relief of bronchospasm in asthma attacks (rescue medication).

Long-acting beta-agonists (LABAs)

Salmeterol, Formoterol

Prolonged stimulation of beta-2 receptors for bronchodilation.

Maintenance therapy (always used with ICS).

Anticholinergics (Short-acting)

Ipratropium

Blocks muscarinic receptors, reducing bronchoconstriction.

Alternative or additive for acute asthma, especially with SABAs.

Inhaled Corticosteroids (ICS) (Option B)
 

Beclomethasone, Budesonide, Fluticasone

Reduces airway inflammation and prevents exacerbations

First-line maintenance therapy in persistent asthma.

Leukotriene Receptor Antagonists (LTRAs)

Montelukast, Zafirlukast

Blocks leukotriene receptors, reducing inflammation and bronchoconstriction.

Maintenance therapy, especially in mild asthma or aspirin-induced asthma.

Mast Cell Stabilizers

Sodium Cromoglycate, Nedocromil

Inhibits mast cell degranulation, reducing mediator release.

Preventive therapy for mild persistent asthma or exercise-induced asthma.

Biologics

Omalizumab

Binds to IgE, preventing its interaction with receptors on mast cells.

Moderate to severe allergic asthma uncontrolled with ICS and LABAs.

Methylxanthines

(Option A)
 

Theophylline, Aminophylline

Non-selective phosphodiesterase inhibition leads to bronchodilation and anti-inflammatory effects.

Add-on therapy in severe or difficult-to-control asthma.

Most commonly used in COPD rather than asthma.

Explanation:

Types of beta-blocker

Examples

Uses

Non-selective beta-blocker

Propranolol, nadolol
  • Hypertension
  • Angina
  • Arrhythmias
  • Migraine prophylaxis

Beta-1-selective blockers

Metoprolol, Atenolol
  • Hypertension
  • Heart failure
  • Arrhythmias

Beta-1-with Alpha-1 blockade

Carvedilol, Labetalol

Side effects of beta-blocker

Cardiac side effects

  • Precipitation of an acute MI.
  • Sinus bradycardia and heart block. (Option C)
  • Heart failure may exacerbate symptoms in patients with decompensated heart failure or preexisting myocardial dysfunction.

Extracardiac side effects

  • Increased airway resistance; hence, it is contraindicated in patients with asthma due to bronchospasm. (Option A)
  • Exacerbation of peripheral artery disease and worsen claudication and precipitate Raynaud's disease.
  • In Hypoglycemia, Beta-blockers mask the signs seen in a hypoglycemic patient, such as tachycardia.
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Depression, fatigue, and sexual dysfunction such as erectile dysfunction.
  • Weight gain

questions.text: A female patient presented with pain and redness in the great toe. The serum uric acid level is 9.4mg/dl. The physician prescribed a drug for the treatment. Which of the following enzyme is likely to be inhibited by this drug?
A new drug is introduced into the market after which phase of the clinical trials?
questions.explanation:
Clinical trials

Phases

Description

Phase 0
  • Design: An open-label trial
  • Purpose:
    • Check the target binding of a drug
    • Check the pharmacokinetics of the drug
  • Called a micro-dosing trial (100 micrograms dose)
  • Non-mandatory clinical trial

Phase I

(Option A)
  • Design: An open-label trial
  • Purpose:
    • Evaluate drug safety- the most important
    • Evaluate MTD (maximum tolerable dose), loading dose, and drug half-life.
    • Evaluate drug pharmacokinetics (absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion)
  • Called the first human trial

Phase II

(Option B)
  • Design: Randomized clinical trial (RCT)
  • Purpose:
    • Explore drug efficacy
  • Called a therapeutic exploratory trial or proof of concept trial

Phase III
  • Design: Double-blinded RCT
  • Purpose:
    • Find the optimal drug dose
    • Confirm efficacy
    • Safety is priority
  • Called a therapeutic confirmatory trial
  • Called multi-site trial (done on a heterogeneous population)
  • Drugs get market approval

Phase IV

(Option D)
  • Design: Open-label
  • Purpose:
    • Find hidden/missed/rare adverse effects.
    • Evaluate compliance: long-term side effects
    • Drug interactions
    • Food interactions
  • Called post-marketing surveillance

Tamoxifen

MOA

  • Antagonist in breast tissue (prevents estrogen binding).
  • Agonist in bone and cardiovascular tissues (estrogen-like effects)

Clinical Use

Side Effects

  • Thromboembolism

Drug Interactions

  • SSRIs inhibit the CYP2D6 enzyme, essential for converting tamoxifen into its active form, endoxifen.
  • This interaction may lower endoxifen levels, diminishing tamoxifen's effectiveness against estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.

questions.text: Which monoclonal antibody is used in cancer treatment?

Rituximab

A chimeric murine/human monoclonal IgG1 antibody targets the CD20 B-cell surface antigen.

MOA

Upon binding to CD20, it induces B-cell lysis through two main mechanisms:

  • Complement-Dependent Cytotoxicity (CDC) and
  • Antibody-Dependent Cellular Cytotoxicity (ADCC).

Uses
  • CD-20 positive B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Pemphigus vulavaris

Pharmacokinetics

Half-life of 22 days

Side effects
  • Infusion reaction - fever, rash and joint pain
  • Upper respiratory tract infections
  • Steven johnson syndrome
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • HBV reactivation
  • Tumor lysis syndrome
  • Cytokine release syndrome

Note

Pretreatment with antihistamines, antipyretics and glucocorticoids reduces the risk of hypersensitivity reactions

Stage

Symptoms

Onset after last drink

Mild withdrawal
  • Mild anxiety
  • Tremulousness
  • Nausea

6-8 hours

Moderate (Alcoholic hallucinosis)

8- 12 hours

12-24 hours

Within 72 hours

Types of delusions

Delusion

Description

Delusion of Persecution
  • Belief of being harassed, persecuted, or mistreated by others.
  • Most common type of delusion. (Option C)

Delusion of Reference
  • The belief that surrounding people are talking about them or spying on them. It is a form of delusion of persecution. (Option D ruled out)

Delusion of Grandiosity
  • Exaggerated belief in one's own importance, power, or identity.
  • Belief in being a significant figure who can help others or may claim to hear the voices of God, which reinforces their belief in their elevated status.
  • Seen in mania (as Mood-congruent delusion)

Nihilistic Delusion
  • Belief that the body/part of body/world or everything related to it has ceased to exist.
  • Also known as the delusion of negation.
  • seen in depression (most commonly) as (Mood-congruent delusion)
  • Cotard syndrome: Patient with depression having delusions of nihilism (specifically related to parts of the body).

Delusion of guilt
  • The patient firmly believes that he is a sinner, though not having committed any sin.
  • Seen in depression (as Mood-congruent delusion)

Delusion of Poverty
  • The patient is convinced that he is poor and in a state of destitution, although he is not.

Delusion of enormity
  • The patient believes that their action can produce catastrophe.
  • Eg, the patient refuses to urinate because he believes that it may flood the world.

Delusion of Infidelity
  • The belief that one's partner is unfaithful.
  • Associated factor: prolonged alcohol use
  • Also known as Othello syndrome/Morbid jealousy

De clerambault’s syndrome/ Erotomania
  • The patient (often a single woman) believes that a person of higher status is in love with her.
  • May be a feature of paranoid schizophrenia.

Hypochondriacal delusion/Delusion of ill health
  • Characteristically seen in depression, it may also be seen in schizophrenia.

Various forms of Hypochondriacal delusion:

Delusion of Infestation/ Parasitosis/ Ekbom syndrome:

  • The patient falsely believes that he is infested with insects,he does not experience sensation.
  • It affects both men and women equally and becomes more common with age.
  • ‘Empty matchbox sign’ may be present (when the patient attempts to catch the insect to show it to the clinician).

Delusional dysmorphophobia:

  • The patient believes that his body/part of his body is deformed and wants it to be corrected.

Delusional halitosis:

  • The belief that the patient has a malodorous body odour.

Preoperative assessment of oral cavity for endotracheal intubation in an adult is done by:

The parents of a 13-year-old boy have sought the assistance of a child psychiatrist due to their concerns. They have observed that the child frequently engages in dishonesty both at home and in school, displays disruptive behaviour towards his teacher, often intimidates younger children, and has been caught stealing money multiple times. What is the probable diagnosis for this child?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Conduct disorder.

Disorder

Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD)

Conduct Disorder

Definition

The persistent pattern of negativistic, defiant, disobedient, and hostile behaviour toward authority figures.

(Option A ruled out)

A persistent pattern of behaviour involving aggression, violating others' rights, and disregarding social norms.

(Option B)

Diagnostic Criteria (DSM-5)

  • Duration: ≥6 months.

  • Symptoms (≥4):

    • Losing temper.

    • Easily annoyed/sensitive.

    • Angry/resentful.

    • Argues with authority figures.

    • Refuses requests/rules.

    • Deliberately annoys others.

    • Blames others for their own mistakes/behaviors.

    • Spiteful/vindictive (at least 2x in 6 months).

    • No severely aggressive or delinquent behaviours.

  • Duration: ≥12 months, with 1 symptom present in the last 6 months.

  • Symptoms (≥3):

    • Physical aggression or threats.

    • Destruction of property.

    • Deceitfulness or theft.

    • Harming animals.

    • Violation of rules (e.g., truancy, running away).

Types (DSM-5)

  • Angry/Irritable Mood: Frequent temper loss, persistent irritability.

  • Argumentative/Defiant Behavior: Argues, refuses to comply, blames others.

  • Vindictiveness: Spiteful/vindictive actions ≥2x in 6 months.

  • Childhood-onset: Symptoms before age 10.

  • Adolescent-Onset: Symptoms after age 10.

  • Unspecified-Onset: Age of onset unknown

Severity Specifiers

  • Mild: Symptoms in 1 setting.

  • Moderate: Symptoms in 2 settings.

  • Severe: Symptoms in ≥3 settings.

  • Mild: Few conduct problems, minor harm.

  • Moderate: Intermediate symptoms.

  • Severe: Many symptoms, significant harm caused.

Treatment

  • Family Interventions: Parent training in child management, reinforcing positive behaviour.

  • Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Parents are taught to discourage the child's oppositional behaviour by not paying much attention to it.

  • Parenting Techniques: Focus on reducing harsh punishment and increasing positive interactions.

  • Psychosocial Interventions: Early intervention, CBT, school-based programs.

  • Pharmacologic Interventions: Antipsychotics (risperidone, quetiapine), SSRIs for impulsivity/irritability, sodium valproate.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 35-year-old woman who experiences heightened anxiety and recurrent thoughts about her hands being contaminated, leading her to frequently wash her hands? Despite finding these thoughts distressing, she is unable to resist them, and attempting to refrain from washing only worsens her anxiety.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Obsessive-compulsive disorder.

Obsessions

Compulsions
  • Intrusive and unwanted repetitive thoughts, urges, or impulses.
  • Most common: Contamination
  • Repetitive actions or thoughts carried out in a strict, regulation-bound manner or reaction to obsessions.
  • Performed to relieve anxiety or fear.
  • Most common: Checking

Symptom Pattern

Description

Contamination/Cleansing

Obsession with contamination, followed by washing/avoidance.

Pathological Doubt/Checking

Obsession with doubt, followed by compulsive checking.

Intrusive/Forbidden Thoughts

Intrusive thoughts of aggression or sexual acts, without compulsion.

Symmetry/Ordering

Need for symmetry or precision, leading to compulsive slowness.

Other Symptoms

Religious obsessions and compulsive hoarding.

Treatment

Description

Pharmacotherapy

First line: SSRIs (preferred), Clomipramine. Treatment for 1-2 years.

Augmenting agents: Antipsychotics (Risperidone, Aripiprazole), Memantine, Riluzole, Ketamine, Lamotrigine, N-acetylcysteine (NAC).

Psychotherapy

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Exposure and response prevention (ERP).

Other therapies: Desensitization, Thought-stopping, Flooding, Aversive conditioning, Psychodynamic psychotherapy, and Family therapy.

CBT is preferred in younger patients. Combination of CBT and pharmacotherapy is useful.

Somatic Therapies

Anterior cingulotomy, Capsulotomy, Deep brain stimulation with electrodes.

questions.text: What is the most probable cause for a 22-year-old man who has a high-grade fever, a purpuric rash, and a CSF sample showing gram-negative diplococci?
questions.explanation:
Clinical features

Description

Consciousness

Decreased level of consciousness occurs in >75% of cases, ranging from lethargy to coma.

Kernig's Sign

Positive when passive extension of the knee elicits pain; indicative of meningeal irritation.

Brudzinski's Sign

Positive when passive flexion of the neck results in spontaneous flexion of the hips and knees; also indicative of meningeal irritation.

Pupils

May present as dilated and poorly reactive due to increased intracranial pressure (ICP).

Posturing

Possible decerebrate posturing as a sign of severe CNS dysfunction.

Signs of Increased ICP

Includes elevated CSF opening pressure (>180 mmH2O), papilledema, and potential cerebral herniation (1–8% incidence).

Additional Symptoms

Nausea, vomiting, photophobia; seizures in 15–40% (focal or generalized).

Meningococcemia Rash

Erythematous maculopapular rash that quickly becomes petechial, commonly on the trunk and lower extremities.

questions.text: Stain used to demonstrate fungal elements are?
questions.explanation:
Method

Description

Use

Direct Microscopic Examination

KOH Preparation

Dissolves keratin in clinical specimens (e.g., skin scrapings, nail clippings) to visualise fungal elements.

Diagnosing dermatophyte infections

Calcofluor White Staining

Enhances fungal visibility by binding to chitin in cell walls, causing them to fluoresce under UV light.

Observing fungal morphology

Gram Stain

Traditionally for bacterial identification; also useful for yeasts, which typically stain Gram-positive (purple).

Detecting certain fungi

India Ink Preparation

Negative staining method for encapsulated yeasts (e.g., Cryptococcus neoformans), revealing a clear halo around cells.

Identifying encapsulated yeasts

Methenamine Silver and PAS Staining

Histochemical techniques that stain fungi black (methenamine) or magenta (PAS) in tissue sections.

Highlighting fungi in tissues

Lactophenol Cotton Blue (LCB) Mount

Enhances contrast in teased fungal colonies for morphological observation.

Microscopic examination of fungi

Serology

Antibody Detection

Identifies antibodies produced by the host in response to fungi using methods like ELISA.

Tracking immune response to fungal infections

Antigen Detection

Detects fungal antigens in body fluids using techniques such as latex agglutination tests.

Identifying fungal presence in the body

Skin Tests

Delayed-Type Hypersensitivity (DTH)

Assesses previous exposure to fungi through localised reactions to injected antigens.

Evaluating past fungal exposure

Newer Rapid Diagnostic Tests

Nucleic Acid Hybridisation

Uses labelled DNA probes for rapid fungal DNA detection in clinical samples.

Quick identification of fungal pathogens

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)

Amplifies specific fungal DNA sequences, enabling early diagnosis even with low fungal loads.

Early detection of fungal infections

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with a penetrating injury to the left eye was treated with corneoscleral suturing. Two months later, he returned with complaints of reduced near vision, pain, redness, and sensitivity to light in his right eye. Direct ophthalmoscopy revealed nodules in the fundus. Which part of the eye is affected?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Uvea

Sympathetic ophthalmitis (SO)

Definition

Bilateral, granulomatous, panuveitis (Option A) occurring after penetrating trauma where uveal prolapse may have been a feature of the trauma

Etiology and pathogenesis
  • Trauma to one eye (exciting eye) — 2 weeks to 3 months — Uveitis in the uninjured eye (sympathizing eye).
  • T-cell mediated autoimmune hypersensitivity reaction to Retinal S antigen.
  • Maximum risk upon injury to the ciliary body.

Histopathology
  • Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration of the choroid.
  • Scattered aggregates of epithelioid cells are seen, many of which contain fine granules of melanin.
  • Dalen–Fuchs nodules - granulomas located between Bruch membrane and the RPE (also seen in VKH syndrome)

Clinical features
  • The exciting eye is frequently red and irritable.
  • The sympathizing eye develops irritation, blurred vision, photophobia and loss of accommodation causing difficulty in near vision (first symptom)
  • Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, which may be mild or severe and is usually granulomatous

Investigations
  • Fundus exam: Dalen–Fuchs nodules, Exudative retinal detachment, vasculitis and optic disc swelling.
  • As inflammation settles, residual chorioretinal scarring may confer a ‘sunset glow’ appearance similar to VKH.
  • B-scan ultrasonography: Choroidal thickening and retinal detachment

Treatment
  • Enucleation of a severely injured eye within 10 to 14 days of the injury is effective in preventing or reducing the severity of SO
  • Steroids are the basis of initial treatment. Intravenous methylprednisolone followed by high-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months and gradually tapered according to response. Supplementary topical steroids and cycloplegics may be given

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the patient having the following type of karyotype, as shown in the image?
In which diseases are microaneurysms observed?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Diabetic retinopathy

Early NPDR or Background Diabetic Retinopathy

Severe NPDR or Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy
  • Affects small retinal vessels.
  • Earliest sign: Microaneurysm (Option B)
    • Fluorescein angiography (FA): Tiny hyperfluorescent dots.
  • Retinal hemorrhages: Both deep, i.e., in the inner nuclear or outer plexiform layer (dot and blot hemorrhage) and superficial, i.e., in nerve fiber layer (splinter or flame-shaped) hemorrhages
  • Hard exudates:
    • White or yellow waxy patches with well-defined margins, often at the posterior pole, in the outer plexiform layer.
    • FA: Hypofluorescence with dense exudates.
  • Edema is not marked.
  • Increased inner retinal hypoxia: Leads to multiple retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, venous beading, vascular loops, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMAs), and large areas of capillary nonperfusion.
  • Cotton-Wool Spots:
    • Also called soft exudates or nerve fiber infarcts.
    • Result from ischemia, not exudation.
    • Caused by obstruction of axoplasmic flow, leading to swelling and a white, fluffy appearance.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence due to local ischemia.
  • Venous Beading:
    • Indicates sluggish retinal circulation.
    • Typically adjacent to large areas of capillary nonperfusion.
  • Intraretinal Microvascular Abnormalities (IRMA):
    • Dilated capillaries act as collateral channels.
    • Bypass capillary bed and is often seen adjacent to capillary nonperfusion.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets?

options.label: C
options.text: It is the most common cause of rickets

questions.explanation:
X-Linked Hypophosphatemic (XLH) Rickets

Prevalence

1 in 20,000. Most common among genetic disorders causing rickets

Inheritance

X-linked dominant

Gene Mutated
  • PHEX (phosphate-regulating gene with homology to endopeptidases on X chromosome)
  • Normally, product of this gene appears to have an indirect role in inactivating FGF-23

Pathophysiology

 

 

Clinical Manifestations
  • Lower limb deformities:
    • Coxa vara
    • Genu valgum
    • Genu varum
  • Poor growth
  • Maxillofacial abnormalities
  • Skull deformities: Due to premature fusion of cranial sutures
  • Delayed dentition
  • Short stature

Laboratory Findings
  • High renal phosphate excretion
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
  • Normal PTH and serum calcium
  • Low or inappropriately normal levels of 1,25-D

Treatment
  • Phosphorus Supplementation:
    • 1-3 g elemental phosphorus daily, divided into 4-5 doses
    • Can be given in the form of Joulie solution (30.4 mg phosphate/mL) or as neutral phosphate effervescent tablets
    • Frequent dosing helps to prevent prolonged decrements in serum phosphorus because there is rapid decline after each dose
  • Calcitriol: 30-70 ng/kg/day in 2 doses
  • Burosumab-twza: Monoclonal antibody targeting FGF-23, an alternative for children >1 year

Prognosis

Generally good response to therapy, though frequent dosing can affect compliance

questions.explanation:
Management of Immune thrombocytopenic purpura in children

Based on platelet count:

  • Platelet Count >30,000 cells/μL + No severe bleeding- Monitor closely
  • Platelet Count < 30,000 cells/μL + No severe bleeding + Platelet Count ≥ 5,000 cells/μL: Glucocorticoids (e.g., Prednisone, Dexamethasone)
  • Platelet Count < 5,000 cells/μL or Severe Bleeding: i.v.i.g.+ Glucocorticoids

Other modalities:

 
  • Immediate Need to Raise Platelet Count like surgery or trauma- Platelet Transfusion
  • Persistent or Severe Cases- Monitor with intermittent i.v.i.g.
  • If necessary, consider Splenectomy

Alternative Medications:
  • Anti-CD20 Antibody: Rituximab
  • TPO Receptor Agonists: Romiplostim, Eltrombopag

questions.text: Which of the following malignant tumors, commonly found in children, has a high tendency to spread to the bone marrow?
questions.explanation:
Neuroblastoma

Definition & Epidemiology
  • Neural crest-derived tumor
  • Most common extracranial solid tumor in children
  • 7-8% of all childhood cancers
  • Most common in first year of life
  • Median age at diagnosis: 19 months

Genetic Features
  • MYCN amplification (~20% of cases)
  • Loss of heterozygosity: 1p, 11q, 14q, 17q
  • TERT and chromatin remodeling genes
  • 1-2% show family history
  • Higher MYCN copy number indicates worse prognosis

Clinical Presentation

Primary Sites:

  • Abdominal (65%)
  • Mediastinal (40%)
  • Paraspinal (19%)
  • Head/neck (5%)

 

Symptoms:

  • Pain, fever, irritability
  • Weight loss
  • Abdominal distension
  • Periorbital ecchymosis
  • Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome (rare)

International Staging

Stage L1: Localized tumor, complete excision

Stage IIA: Incomplete gross excision

Stage IIB: Complete/incomplete excision with positive lymph nodes

Stage III: Midline crossing or bilateral involvement

Stage IV: Distant metastasis (Bone marrow (MC), bone, liver, regional lymph nodes)

Stage IVS: Localized primary with limited dissemination (infants)

Diagnostic Markers

Immunohistochemistry:

  • Synaptophysin
  • Tyrosine hydroxylase
  • PHOX2B
  • Neuron-specific enolase

 

Other Markers:

  • Desmin
  • Myogenin
  • Keratin
  • CD99

Treatment Options

Primary Treatments:

  • Surgery
  • Chemotherapy
  • Radiation therapy

 

Chemotherapy Regimens:

  • OPEC (vincristine, cyclophosphamide, cisplatin)
  • CADO (vincristine, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin)
  • PECADO (cisplatin, etoposide)

 

Additional Therapies:

  • 13-cis retinoic acid
  • Autologous bone marrow transplantation

questions.text: Arlt’s line is seen in?

Correct Option C - Trachoma

Signs of active trachoma

Signs of cicatricial trachoma

Conjunctival signs:

  • Conjunctival congestion
  • Follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva: Look like sago-grains
  • Papillary enlargement: red, velvety

Conjunctival signs:

    • Linear scar in the sulcus subtarsalis is called Arlt’s line (Option C)
  • accumulation of dead epithelial cells and inspissated mucus in the glands of Henle
  • Pseudocyst
  • Xerosis
  • Symblepharon

Corneal signs:

  • Superficial keratitis on slit lamp and fluorescein
  • Herbert’s follicles
  • Progressive pannus/Trachomatous pannus: The upper part of the cornea is cloudy
  • Corneal ulcers are common at the advancing edge of the pannus
    • Shallow, little infiltrated
    • Cause lacrimation and photophobia

Corneal signs:

  • Regressive pannus or pannus siccus:
    • Receding infiltration
    • Vessels extend beyond the area of infiltration and haze
  • Herbert pits: oval or circular pitted scars formed after the healing of Herbert’s follicles in the limbal area
  • Vascularized and opaque cornea.
  • Corneal xerosis
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Total corneal pannus (blinding sequelae)

 

 

Lid signs:

  • Distortion of the lids
  • Tylosis : Thickening of the tarsal plate/lid margin
  • Trichiasis due to rubbing of lashes on the cornea
  • Trachomatous ptosis (sleepy appearance)
  • Entropion
  • Madarosis
  • Ankyloblepharon

Lacrimal apparatus sequelae:

  • Chronic dacryocystitis
  • Chronic dacryoadenitis

Active Trachoma

 

Follicles in upper palpebral conjunctiva

 

Trachomatous pannus

Progressive pannus

Cicatricial

Trachoma

​​​​​​

Conjunctival concretions

 

Trichiasis

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented the findings shown in the given image. What is this physical finding called?
questions.explanation:
Clubbing of fingers

Definition
  • Enlargement of distal segments of fingers and toes
  • Proliferation of connective tissue
  • Particularly on the dorsal surface
  • Changes at the base of clubbed nail

Pathophysiology
  • Connective tissue proliferation
  • Exact mechanism unknown
  • Platelet-derived growth factors implicated

Clinical Signs
  • Bulbous Enlargement of the Distal Phalanges
  • Loss of the Normal Angle Between the Nail and the Nailbed (Lovibond’s Angle)
  • Increased Sponginess of the Soft Tissue at the Base of the Nail
  • Nail Changes:
  • Nail flattening/nail curvature
  • Hippocratic fingers: The tips of the fingers become enlarged, and the nails curve downward

Clinical tests

Schamroth’s Sign:

  • Normal: A small diamond-shaped window should be visible between the nails when the fingers are positioned in this way.
  • Positive Schamroth’s Sign: The window disappears, and there is no gap between the nails, indicating the loss of the normal angle at the nail bed.

Associated Conditions
  • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
  • Infective endocarditis
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Cystic Fibrosis
  • Lung cancer
  • Tuberculosis
  • Inflammatory bowel disease

Key Features
  • Can be hereditary or acquired
  • May be reversible in certain circumstances
  • Associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy
  • Can cause pain and arthritis-like changes

questions.text: Which of the following agents is most likely causing the condition in a 60-year-old woman, who had a kidney transplant 2 months ago, and is now experiencing a high fever, severe difficulty in breathing, and a dry cough with a hacking sound? A chest x-ray shows widespread interstitial infiltrates in both lungs, and urine examination reveals the presence of cells with an 'owl-eye' appearance.
questions.explanation:
Complications following Renal transplant

Graft rejection

Hyperacute, acute and chronic

Opportunistic infections

 
  • < 1 Month: Wound infection, HSV, UTI, Oral candidiasis
  • 1-6 Months: CMV (most common), HBV, HCV, Pneumocystis carinii, Listeria
  • >6 Months: BK Virus, Aspergillus, Nocardia, HBV, HCV, HZV

Hypercalcemia

This may indicate failure of parathyroid gland regression post-transplant.

Anemia

Common post-transplant, often due to immunosuppressive medications. Gastrointestinal bleeding can occur from steroid use.

Chronic hepatitis

Particularly from hepatitis B virus, which can progress over time.

Skin and lip cancers

Most common malignancy

The leading causes of death among kidney transplant recipients include:

  • Cardiovascular events (29%)
  • Infections (18%)
  • Malignancies (17%)

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with unsteady gait, forgetfulness, and labile moods. During a physical exam, the neurologist notices the findings shown in the image below. The most likely diagnosis is:

A 53-year-old patient was brought to the emergency room with a history of alcohol abuse, altered sensorium, and rapid shallow breathing. His abdomen is distended with palpable hepatomegaly and splenomegaly and sclerae are icteric. The other examination findings are given below. Laboratory tests show that the AST: ALT ratio is 3:1. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.explanation:
Pathophysiology

Alcohol Metabolism
  • Ethanol is primarily metabolized in the liver by enzymes, particularly alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) and cytochrome P450 2E1 (CYP2E1).
  • This metabolism produces acetaldehyde, a toxic intermediate, which can cause cellular damage.

Oxidative Stress
  • The metabolism of alcohol generates reactive oxygen species (ROS) and increases oxidative stress within liver cells.
  • This oxidative damage leads to lipid peroxidation, protein modifications, and DNA damage, contributing to hepatocyte injury and inflammation.

Inflammatory Response
  • Alcohol consumption stimulates the activation of immune cells (e.g., Kupffer cells) leading to the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6).
  • These cytokines promote inflammation and can further damage hepatocytes.

Altered Lipid Metabolism
  • Alcohol disrupts normal lipid metabolism, leading to fat accumulation in liver cells (steatosis).
  • This accumulation can progress to steatohepatitis, where inflammation and liver cell injury occur.

Fibrosis and Cirrhosis
  • Chronic inflammation and injury stimulate the activation of hepatic stellate cells, which produce collagen and lead to fibrosis.
  • Over time, repeated injury can result in cirrhosis, characterized by scarring and loss of normal liver architecture.

General
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Fever, malaise, jaundice, history of alcohol intake + (at least within last 8 weeks before symptom onset)

Abdominal
  • Right upper quadrant pain, tender hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, ascites
  • Caput medusae: enlarged veins radiating from the umbilicus
  • Bleeding varices (portal hypertension)

Dermatological
  • Spider angioma, palmar erythema, ecchymosis

Reproductive
  • Gynaecomastia, gonadal atrophy, loss of libido, amenorrhea

Neurological
  • Peripheral neuropathy: tingling and numbness usually over feet
  • Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome: Ophthalmoplegia, confusion, ataxia + anterograde amnesia
  • Hepatic encephalopathy: Asterixis (most prominent finding), altered sensorium, sleep disturbances, lethargy

Others
  • Dupuytren’s contracture, temporal muscle wasting, parotid gland enlargement

AST (Aspartate aminotransferase)

Non-specific ; ↑ (<300-400)

ALT (Alanine aminotransferase)

Specific for liver injury ; ↑ (<300-400)

AST/ALT ratio: ≥ 2: 1

Specific for ALD

ALP (Alkaline phosphatase)

Elevated in bile duct pathologies

GGT (γ-glutamyl transferase)

Non-specific marker of ALD

5’-Nucleotidase

Specific marker for bile duct pathologies

S.Bilirubin

Usually normal/mildly ↑

S.Albumin

↓ in chronic liver disease (cirrhosis)

Carbohydrate-deficient transferrin (CDT)

Best serum marker for alcoholic liver disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is experiencing chronic pain in his hands, knees, and hips, with increased pain in the hands during writing or typing. Additionally, he has morning stiffness in his joints that lasts for about 30 minutes. On examination, Heberden's and Bouchard's nodes are visible in the hands, and an X-ray of the knee shows narrowed joint space with osteophytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)

(Option C)

Osteoarthritis (OA)

(Option B)

Psoriatic Arthritis

Gout

Reactive Arthritis

Joint Involvement Pattern

Symmetrical involvement of small joints (MCP, PIP)

Asymmetrical involvement, especially DIP joints

Asymmetrical involvement, often DIP joints

Typically involves a single joint (e.g., big toe)

Asymmetrical involvement, often larger joints

Morning Stiffness

Lasts over 1 hour

Resolves within 30 minutes

Varies, often significant

Rarely significant

Variable often follows infection

Key Symptoms

Swelling, tenderness, deformities (e.g., ulnar deviation)

Pain and stiffness with use

Dactylitis, nail changes

Sudden, severe pain and swelling

Joint pain following an infection

Affected Joints

MCP, PIP, wrists, knees

Knees, hips, hands (DIP, PIP)

MCP, PIP, and can include spine and tendons

Typically big toe (1st MTP joint)

Larger joints (e.g., knees, ankles)

Radiographic Findings

Soft tissue swelling, joint space narrowing

Osteophytes, joint space narrowing

Erosions, possible nail changes

Erosions and tophi possible

Similar to RA but typically larger joints

questions.text: A girl experiences prolonged menstrual bleeding and has normal platelet count, PT, and aPTT, but an increased bleeding time, which was determined to be due to a deficiency of GpIIb-IIIa after further analysis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Tests

Results

aPTT, PT, and ristocetin cofactor activity

Normal

Bleeding time

Increased

Light transmission aggregometry (LTA) (gold standard test)

Altered platelet aggregation with ADP, collagen, and epinephrine.

Normal aggregation with ristocetin.

Flow cytometry

Defective expression of alpha IIb beta 3 integrin

Molecular genetic tests

Gene mutations in ITGA2B or ITGB3

Therapy

Clinical setting

Desmopressin

Mild bleeding

Platelets and/or recombinant activated clotting factor VII (rFVIIa)

Surgery prophylaxis

Tranexamic acid

Mucocutaneous bleeding

Recombinant FVIIa

Platelet refractoriness cases

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of repeated fractures for the past 2 years. On examination, blue sclera and dental abnormalities are noted. There is a family history of similar complaints. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Pathophysiology

Defective type I collagen synthesis

Genetic Mutations

Type I-IV: COL1A1, COL1A2

Type V: IFITM5

Type VI: SERPINF1

Key Clinical Features

Recurrent fractures from minimal trauma, blue sclerae, hearing loss, joint hypermobility, osteopenia

Complications

Cardiopulmonary issues (pneumonia, cor pulmonale), neurological complications (basilar invagination, brainstem compression)

Differential Diagnosis

Rickets, osteopetrosis, and disorders related to abnormal calcium metabolism

Treatment

Physical rehabilitation, Bisphosphonates, growth hormone, orthopedic management (fracture care, surgery)

questions.text: A patient exhibits symptoms of increased urination, nighttime urination, and involuntary urination, along with a recorded 24-hour urine volume of 7 litres. He has a urine osmolarity of 260 mOsm/L. The ADH assay shows a recorded value of 0.8 pg/ml, and an MRI of the brain reveals the absence of a bright spot on T1-weighted imaging. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Central DI

(Option C)

Nephrogenic DI

(Option A)

Primary Polydipsia

(Option B)

Gestational DI

Definition

Deficiency of AVP (Arginine vasopressin) secretion from the pituitary gland.

Kidneys are unable to respond to AVP, even if levels are normal.

Excessive water intake suppresses AVP secretion.

Increased activity of placental enzyme degrading AVP during pregnancy.

Causes

Acquired: Head trauma, tumours, granulomas, infections, inflammation, toxins, vascular events, hypoxia.

 

Acquired: Drugs (lithium, demeclocycline), metabolic disorders (hypercalcaemia, hypokalaemia), obstruction, vascular issues, granulomas, tumours, and infiltration.

Dipsogenic: Inappropriate thirst, head trauma, brain diseases.

Increased placental vasopressinase activity.

Psychogenic: Psychiatric conditions, compulsive water drinking.

Genetic: Mutations in the AVP–neurophysin II or WFS1 genes.

 

Genetic: Mutations in the V2 receptor or aquaporin-2 genes.

Iatrogenic: Belief in the health benefits of excessive water intake.

Basal Plasma AVP

Low or undetectable (<1 pg/mL).

Normal or elevated (>1 pg/mL).

Low due to suppression by excessive water intake.

Low due to increased degradation.

Urine Osmolarity

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L) but can temporarily concentrate with fluid deprivation.

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Plasma Osmolarity

Increased

Increased

Decreased

Increased

Fluid Deprivation Test
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection increases urine osmolarity in severe CDI.
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection does not affect severe NDI.

Plasma osmolarity and sodium increase above normal without urine concentration.

Not typically performed during pregnancy.

MRI

Posterior pituitary bright spot absent or small.

The posterior pituitary bright- spot may be faint or absent.

Posterior pituitary bright spot present.

Not routinely used for diagnosis.

Desmopressin (DDAVP) Trial

Abolishes polyuria and polydipsia; reduces plasma osmolarity/sodium.

No effect on urine output, fluid intake, or plasma osmolarity/sodium.

Eliminates polyuria but not polydipsia, leading to hyponatremia.

Effective in controlling symptoms.

Plasma Copeptin

Low or undetectable.

It may be normal or elevated.

Suppressed due to low AVP.

It may be low due to AVP degradation.

Treatment

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Thiazide diuretics, amiloride, low-sodium diet, prostaglandin inhibitors.

Behavioural therapy, education about overhydration.

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Resolution
  • Lifelong treatment is usually needed for acquired CDI
  • Genetic forms may improve.
  • Dependent on the underlying cause
  • Lithium-induced NDI may persist.
  • Dependent on behavioural modification and addressing the underlying cause.
  • Usually, it resolves after delivery.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. As there was no pulse, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the monitor showed the following rhythm. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Shockable Conditions

Non-Shockable Conditions

Ventricular Fibrillation

Asystole

Ventricular Tachycardia

Pulseless Electrical Activity

Shockable Conditions

Non-Shockable Conditions

Immediate Recognition

Identify Shockable Rhythm: Recognize VF or pulseless VT.

Activate Emergency Response: Call for advanced life support.

↓

Initiate CPR

Start High-Quality CPR: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120/min, with a depth of 5-6 cm. Continue CPR for 2 minutes.

↓

Defibrillation (Option A)

After 2 minutes of CPR, deliver a Non-Synchronized DC Shock to restore normal rhythm.

If no change, administer a second shock immediately.

↓

Continue CPR

Resume CPR for 2 Minutes

Place an intravenous or intraosseous line for drug administration.

↓

Administer Epinephrine

Epinephrine 1 mg (Option C) (1:10,000): Given IV/IO after 2 minutes of CPR to enhance coronary perfusion pressure.

↓

Advanced Airway Management

Secure Airway: Perform endotracheal intubation if necessary.

Capnography: Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels.

Ventilation: Provide 1 breath every 6 seconds post-intubation.

↓

Further Defibrillation

Third Shock: If VF or pulseless VT persists, deliver a third non-synchronized shock.

Continue CPR for 2 More Minutes: Follow with additional CPR.

↓

Administer Antiarrhythmic Medication

Amiodarone 300 mg IV: Administer for shock-refractory VT to stabilize heart rhythm.

↓

Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

Immediate Recognition

Identify Non-Shockable Rhythm: Recognize asystole or pulseless electrical activity (PEA).

Activate Emergency Response: Call for advanced life support.

↓
Initiate CPR

Start High-Quality CPR: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120/min, with a depth of 5-6 cm. Continue CPR for 2 minutes.

↓
Establish intravenous or intraosseous lines for medication administration.

↓
Administer Epinephrine

Epinephrine 1 mg (1:10,000): Administer IV/IO after the first 2 minutes of CPR.

↓

Identify Rhythm

  • Non-Shockable Rhythm: Continue CPR and administer epinephrine every 3-5 minutes.

Goal: To increase the likelihood of developing a shockable rhythm, such as ventricular fibrillation (VF), which is necessary for effective defibrillation.

  • Shockable Rhythm: Administer a Non-Synchronized DC Shock to restore normal rhythm.

↓
Advanced Airway Management

Airway: Secure the airway with endotracheal intubation if necessary.

Capnography: Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels.

Ventilation: Provide 1 breath every 6 seconds post-intubation for adequate oxygenation.

↓
Continue CPR

Resume chest compressions for 2 minutes.

↓
Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

Primary Focus: Address reversible causes, especially hypothermia.

↓
Repeat CPR and Epinephrine

Cycle: Continue repeating CPR and epinephrine administration every 3-5 minutes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with sudden onset of a headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. He had several such episodes in the past. During these episodes, his BP is found to be high. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely aetiology?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Pheochromocytomas are rare tumours arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
  • The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines.

Epidemiology
  • Estimated to occur in 2 to 8 of 1 million persons per year.
  • The mean age at diagnosis is 40 years, although the tumours can occur from early childhood until late in life.
  • The classic ‘rule of tens’ is 10% bilateral, 10% extra-adrenal (Paragangliomas), and 10% metastatic. It is not used nowadays.

Etiopathogenesis
  • These tumors can be benign or malignant and are frequently associated with familial syndromes like
    • Neurofibromatosis type 1,
    • multiple endocrine neoplasia type II, and
    • Von-Hippel Lindau disease.
  • Catecholamines are produced in the chromaffin cells starting with the rate-limiting step of tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), regulating the conversion of tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).
  • Pheochromocytomas release these catecholamines in various patterns ranging from paroxysmal, continuous, and mixed patterns. Norepinephrine is released continuously and can result in persistent hypertension, while epinephrine is released in a paroxysmal pattern resulting in tachyarrhythmias.
    • Ryanodine-2 receptors (RyR2).
    • Beta-2 adrenoceptors
    • Alpha(1)-adrenoreceptors

Histopathology
  • Histology of the lesion characteristically shows zellballen nests of chromaffin cells with strong positivity to chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and focally to S100.
  • The presence of chromaffin cells in the extra-adrenal tissue is the only pathognomonic characteristic of the malignant form of the entity.

Clinical features
  • Classical triad
    • Episode of palpitation
    • Headache
    • Profuse sweating
  • The dominant sign is Hypertension
  • Tachycardia
  • Anxiety
  • Subcutaneous neurofibromas
  • Cafe-au-lait macules
  • Thyroid mass
  • Axillary freckling
  • Lisch nodules on the iris
  • Retinal angiomas
  • Abdominal mass

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines.

24-hour urine test

  • Catecholamines
  • Fractionated metanephrines
  • Total metanephrines

Imaging:

  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumour.
  • 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease.
  • MIBG scintigraphy
  • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning

Differential Diagnosis
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Renal artery stenosis
  • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS)

Treatment
  • The definitive treatment of pheochromocytoma is surgical resection.
  • Preoperative preparation of the patient has to be considered, and blood pressure should be consistently < 160/90 mm Hg.
  • Blood pressure is controlled by alpha-adrenergic blockers(phenoxybenzamine 0.5-4 mg/kg of body weight)
  • Oral Prazosin or IV phentolamine can be used to control paroxysm.

 

Unilateral Pheochromocytoma:

  • Minimally invasive adrenalectomy: Preferred treatment for most unilateral adrenal pheochromocytomas.
  • Open adrenalectomy

 

Bilateral pheochromocytomas:

  • Bilateral total adrenalectomy is associated with a lifelong need for steroid replacement with long-term side effects.
  • Bilateral partial or cortical sparing adrenalectomy (open or laparoscopic)

Complications
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Cardiogenic shock
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy

Which of the following leads to a continuous murmur?
questions.explanation:
Continuous murmur

Definition
  • Murmur that persists across systole and diastole
  • Begins in at S1, continues through second heart sound (S2) and tapers at next S1

Causes
  • Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)
  • Peripheral Pulmonic stenosis
  • Valsalva aneurysm
  • Aortopulmonary window
  • Great vessel arteriovenous fistula
  • Coronary to pulmonic fistula

Mitral Stenosis

Low-pitched diastolic murmur with opening snap, best at the apex

Aortic Stenosis

Systolic ejection murmur, crescendo-decrescendo pattern, radiating to carotids

Patent Ductus Arteriosus / Peripheral Pulmonic Stenosis

A continuous, machine-like murmur, heard at the left infraclavicular area

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy

Harsh systolic murmur, crescendo-decrescendo pattern

Mitral Regurgitation

Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla

Aortic Regurgitation

Early diastolic decrescendo murmur, best heard at the left sternal border

Graham Steell Murmur

Early diastolic decrescendo murmur due to pulmonary regurgitation, heard best at the left upper sternal border.

Austin Flint Murmur

Low-pitched, rumbling diastolic murmur due to severe aortic regurgitation causing turbulent flow in the left ventricle.

Carvallo's Sign

Increased intensity of a tricuspid regurgitation murmur with inspiration, heard along the left lower sternal border.

options.label: A
options.text: Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN

options.label: B
options.text: Muscle intimal elastic lamina layer defect

questions.correct_answer: B. Muscle intimal elastic lamina layer defect
questions.explanation:
Berry Aneurysm

Definition
  • Saccular outpouching of intracranial arterial wall
  • Represents 90% of cerebral aneurysms
  • Primary location: Circle of Willis
  • Most common sites:
    • Anterior communicating/anterior cerebral junction
    • Posterior communicating/internal carotid junction
    • Middle cerebral artery bifurcation
    • Basilar apex

Pathophysiological Mechanisms

Structural Changes:

  • Most important- Internal elastic lamina disruption
  • Media layer thinning
  • Adventitial layer remodeling

Molecular Mechanisms:

  • Inflammatory mediator activation
  • Matrix metalloproteinase upregulation
  • Vessel wall extracellular matrix degradation

Hemodynamic Factors:

  • Wall shear stress elevation
  • Flow-related endothelial injury
  • Intramural stress distribution alterations

Histopathological Classification

1. Mycotic:

  • Infectious arterial wall damage
  • Distal vessel predilection
  • Inflammatory cell infiltration

2. Arteriosclerotic:

  • Intimal hyperplasia
  • Media degeneration
  • Elastic fiber fragmentation

3. Traumatic:

  • Transmural disruption
  • False lumen formation
  • Adventitial hemorrhage

Rupture Risk Stratification

Morphological Criteria:

  • Size >7mm: high risk
  • Aspect ratio >1.6
  • Daughter sac presence
  • Wall irregularity

Hemodynamic Factors:

  • Systolic BP >140 mmHg
  • Flow pattern alterations
  • Intrasaccular pressure gradients

Genetic Markers:

  • Collagen deficiency
  • Elastic fiber abnormalities
  • Matrix metalloproteinase polymorphisms

Clinical Manifestations

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage:

  • Hunt-Hess grading scale correlation
  • Fisher scale for CT findings
  • Modified Rankin Scale outcomes

Mass Effect:

  • Cranial nerve compression syndromes
  • Brainstem compression sequelae
  • Hydrocephalus development

Thromboembolic Events:

  • Watershed infarction patterns
  • Perforator occlusion syndromes
  • Distal embolization phenomena

Correct Option B) Sharp waste

Colour

Waste Type

Type of bag or container to be used

Method of disposal

Yellow
  • All infectious waste.
  • Human anatomical waste. (Option A ruled out)
  • Animal anatomical waste
  • Soiled waste (contaminated with blood, body fluids, dressings and swabs, blood bags).
  • Expired or discarded medicines
  • Chemical waste.
  • Microbiological and other clinical laboratory waste.
  • Yellow coloured non chlorinated plastic bags.
  • Incineration
  • Plasma pyrolysis
  • Deep burial

Red
  • Contaminated waste (recyclable): Tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles), vacutainers and gloves. (Option D ruled out)
  • Red coloured non chlorinated plastic bags.
  • Autoclaving or microwaving/hydroclaving, and then sent for recycling (not to landfill).

Blue
  • Glassware: Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampoules except those contaminated with cytotoxic waste. (Option C ruled out)
  • Metallic body implants.
  • Cardboard boxes with blue coloured markings.
  • Disinfection or autoclaving/microwaving, hydroclaving and then sent to recycling.

White
  • Waste sharps including metals: Needles, syringes with fixed needles, scalpels or any other sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. (Option B)
  • Puncture proof and leak proof containers.
  • Auto or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding and mutilation or encapsulation.

A 10-year-old male child presents with headache and cola-colored urine. His parents report throat pain 2 weeks ago. On examination, red blood cells are present in urine and his KFT is increased two fold. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)

Cause

Group A β-Hemolytic streptococci

Pathogenesis

Immune-complex mediated (Type III hypersensitivity reaction)

Clinical manifestations
  • It is more common in children and young adults.
  • History of impetigo (2-6 weeks) or pharyngitis (1-3 weeks).
  • Pulmonary oedema (shortness of breath, cough, chest pain)
  • Periorbital and pedal oedema
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy:
    • Abrupt rise in BP
    • Headache
    • Loss of consciousness
  • Features of uremia include fatigue, weakness, confusion, swelling over body parts, shortness of breath, abnormal urine output, nausea, and vomiting.

Test for antibodies
  • Anti- DNAse
  • Anti-Hyaluronidase
  • ASO (antistreptolysin O) titer

Lab findings

  • Urine analysis: Red-colored urine, which turns dark (cola-colored) on standing (hematuria).
  • Raised values of renal function test (serum creatinine, urea, etc).
  • Raised serum potassium
  • Low serum levels of C3, IgG & CH50
  • Normal serum C4 level.

Pathological findings
  • Gross findings: Flea-bitten appearance of kidneys

 

  • Light microscopy: Hypercellular glomeruli (increased number of neutrophils, macrophages, endothelial and mesangial cells).

 

  • Electron microscopy: Subepithelial humps (due to immune complex deposition)

 

  • Immunofluorescence study: A starry-sky appearance (Granular) is observed (due to immune complex deposition).

Management

  • Self-limiting disorder
  • Conservative and supportive management involves:
    • HTN crisis: Labetalol (IV), sodium nitroprusside
    • Pulmonary edema: Furosemide
    • Antibiotics (Benzathine penicillin)
    • Dialysis if needed

Identify the fungus shown in the image given below which is stained by India ink dye.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Cryptococcus

Cryptococcus Spp.

Cryptococcus is a true yeast.

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule - helps in serotyping and protection against phagocytosis .

Serotypes

A, D, AD serotypes - Cryptococcus variety neoformans

B, C serotypes -Cryptococcus variety gattii

Virulence factors

  • Polysaccharide Capsule: The primary virulence factor. It helps the pathogen evade phagocytosis and suppresses the host’s local immune responses, enabling the organism to survive and spread.

  • Melanin Production: Cryptococcus produces melanin via the enzyme phenol oxidase, which contributes to its virulence by protecting the pathogen from oxidative stress and immune defenses.

  • Enzyme Production: The fungus secretes several enzymes, including:

    • Phospholipase: Aids in tissue invasion and damage.

    • Urease: Helps the fungus survive in the host environment by neutralizing acidic conditions, enhancing its ability to colonize and spread.

Risk of infection

Immunocompromised States:

  • HIV/AIDS, cancer, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive therapies, extremes of age are at higher risk.

Geographic Location:

  • Exposure to environments where Cryptococcus gattii is endemic, such as tropical and subtropical regions

Environmental Exposure:

  • Exposure to bird droppings or decaying wood can increase the likelihood of infection, especially with C. neoformans.

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells

  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture

  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.

  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.

  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine

  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.

  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.

  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

questions.text: Which organism is the cause of perianal itching in a child who experiences symptoms primarily at night, leading to sleep disturbances? The eggs of the responsible organism can be observed in the accompanying image.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Enterobius vermicularis

Epidemiology:

  • The most common age group being school children.
  • Infections can persist for years due to auto-infective cycles.
  • Factors contributing to infection include:
    • Overcrowding
    • Impaired hygiene
    • Poor personal care practices (such as nail-biting and inadequate handwashing).

Morphology

Adult worm

 
  • The adults are short, white, and fusiform, resembling bits of white thread.
  • The mouth is surrounded by three wing-like structures called cervical alae, which are transversely striated.

Female worm

 
  • Females are long.
  • The posterior third tapers into a thin, pointed, pin-like tail.
  • Females are oviparous.

Male worm
  • The posterior end is tightly curved ventrally, sharply truncated, and has a prominent copulatory spicule.

Eggs

 
  • The eggs are colorless and not bile-stained
  • They float in saturated salt solution and have an elongated ovoid shape.
  • Each egg contains a tadpole-shaped, coiled embryo that becomes infectious only 6 hours after being deposited.

questions.text: What structures are contained within the anterior pararenal space? Head, neck, and body of the pancreas Adrenal gland, kidney, ureters Aorta, inferior vena cava Ascending and descending colon
questions.explanation:
Retroperitoneal spaces

Anterior pararenal space

It contains the head, neck, and body of the pancreas (the tail of the pancreas is within the splenorenal ligament), the ascending and descending colon, and the duodenum (except for the proximal first segment).

Perirenal space

This includes the adrenal gland, kidney, ureters, and renal vessels. (Statement 2 ruled out)

Posterior pararenal space

It is surrounded by the posterior leaf of the renal fascia and muscles of the posterior abdominal wall, contains no major organs and is composed primarily of fat, blood vessels, and lymphatics.

There is also a fourth, less well-defined space known as the great vessel space. It lies anterior to the vertebral bodies and psoas muscles and contains the aorta, inferior vena cava, and surrounding fat. (Statement 3 ruled out)

questions.text: What electrolyte imbalance is commonly observed in patients with this postoperative condition, as depicted in the provided x-ray?
questions.explanation:
Paralytic ileus

Etiology
  • Abdominal surgery.
  • Uremia.
  • Mesenteric ischemia.
  • Retroperitoneal hematoma.
  • Intra-abdominal sepsis.
  • Dyselectrolytemia (e.g. hypokalemia) (Option B)
  • Drugs affecting intestinal motility:
    • Opiates.
    • Antipsychotics.

Clinical Features
  • Abdominal distension.
  • Abdominal discomfort.
  • Non-colicky pain.
  • Vomiting.
  • Non-passage of feces and flatus.
  • Absence of bowel sounds.

Investigations

 

IOC: Abdominal X-ray.

Findings:

  • Dilated bowel loops.
  • Gas in the colon and rectum.
  • Multiple air-fluid levels.

Management

 

Decompression: Nasogastric aspiration.

 

Diet: Restrict oral intake until bowel sounds return or the patient starts passing faeces and flatus.

 

Treatment of Underlying Cause:

  • Correct dyselectrolytemia (e.g., hypokalemia).
  • Discontinue medications affecting motility (e.g., opiates).

questions.text: A 54-year-old farmer from Ohio presents to a physician with a chronic cough. A chest x-ray demonstrates a cavitary lesion with hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy of the lymph node and staining with lactophenol cotton blue demonstrates the following characteristics as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Histoplasmosis:

Histoplasmosis

Causative Agent

Histoplasma capsulatum; thermally dimorphic fungus.

  • H. capsulatum var. capsulatum: Causes classical histoplasmosis.
  • H. capsulatum var. duboisii: Causes African histoplasmosis.

Epidemiology

Endemic to central and eastern USA; also found in Africa.

Route of transmission

Thrives in soil, decaying trees, and bird droppings.

Inhalation of fungal spores.

Clinical manifestations

Classical histoplasmosis is often asymptomatic.

Calcified lesions.

Pulmonary disease mimics tuberculosis.

Disseminated histoplasmosis can occur.

Infection of the reticuloendothelial system causes:

  • Lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anaemia

Skin and mucous membrane: Granulomatous and ulcerative lesions.

African Histoplasmosis:

  • It primarily affects the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and bones
  • Lungs are rarely involved, and disseminated cases are infrequent

Specimens for Diagnosis

Blood, urine, bone marrow, lesions

Diagnosis

Microscopy:

  • Stained smears of the specimens show small intra- and extracellular yeast cells

Culture:

  • Blood agar and Sabouraud agar show characteristic growth
  • White, cottony, mycelial growth with large thick-walled spherical spores with tuberculate (finger-like projections)

Serodiagnosis:

  • Antibody titers increase in progressive disease
  • Antigen tests on urine and serum, are helpful for immunocompromised individuals

Skin Test:

  • Delayed hypersensitivity to histoplasmin confirms exposure

Treatment

Amphotericin-B for two to four weeks followed by a year of itraconazole

questions.text: Which of the following options is considered a high-level disinfectant?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Glutaraldehyde

Risk category

Recommended method

Medical device/Equipment

1. Critical device (high risk): Items that enter a normally sterile site.

Sterilisation

  • If heat resistant: Hot air oven or autoclave
  • If heat-sensitive: Ionising radiation or ethylene oxide or plasma sterilisation.

Surgical instruments, implants/prostheses, rigid endoscopes, syringes, needles, CuT, Urinary catheter

2. Semi-critical device (intermediate risk): Items in contact with mucous membranes or body fluids.
  • High-level disinfection (HLD):
  • Such as glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde, formaldehyde and hydrogen peroxide.

Respiratory equipment, non-invasive flexible endoscopes, bedpans, urine bottles

 

3. Non-critical (low-risk)

Items in contact with intact skin.
  • Intermediate or Low-level disinfection (ILD or LLD):
  • Such as phenols (Option D ruled out), chlorhexidine, isopropyl alcohol (Option A ruled out), povidone-iodine, iodophores (Option C ruled out), etc
  • Patient items include blood pressure cuffs, ECG electrodes, thermometer and stethoscopes.
  • Environmental surfaces include computers, bed rails, food utensils, bedside tables, patient furniture and floor.

questions.text: A barber aged 42 years presented with a healed ulcer as below, over the lower medial aspect of the right leg. On examination, he has varicose veins on both his legs. What is the most likely type of ulcer he had?
questions.explanation:
Venous ulcer

(Option C)

Arterial ulcer

(Option B)

Neuropathic ulcer

(Option A)

Pressure ulcer

 

Site

Gaiter’s area (area between malleolus and calf)

At distal ends of limbs, such as toes, feet and legs.

Over toe joints, under the heel, over malleoli, under the metatarsal head, etc

Seen over pressure points, most common are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, hee, malleolus, occiput, etc

Appearance

Vertically oval with a sloping edge and will not penetrate deep fascia.

Punched-out edges are seen in this type of ulcer.

Ulcers can be associated with gangrene and abscesses; osteomyelitis can be seen here.

Punched out ulcer with bone as a base.

Cause

Caused by ambulatory chronic venous hypertension due to varicose veins.

This occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium-sized arteries, leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region.

It is caused due to repeated trauma and ischemia due to microangiopathy in diabetic patients.

It is tissue necrosis and ulceration due to prolonged pressure on any part of the body.

Characteristics

It is initially painful, then chronically becomes painless.

It heals on rest and treatment but reforms again.

It is intensely painful, and distal pulses are not palpable, and associated with shiny skin, brittle nails and loss of hair over the region.

It is also known as diabetic ulcer since it is seen in diabetic patients.

It is common in bedridden patients with head injuries, neurological deficits, and comatose and stroke-ridden patients.

questions.text: What should be the initial course of action for a patient who has presented with a pelvic fracture and a rupture in the membranous urethra?

options.label: A
options.text: A suprapubic catheter should be inserted as soon as possible

questions.correct_answer: A. A suprapubic catheter should be inserted as soon as possible
questions.explanation:
Investigations, Management & Complications of Posterior Urethral Injuries

Investigations
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard for initial assessment
  • CT Urethrography: Useful in evaluating complex injuries
  • Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures
  • Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation
  • If injury at Prostatomembranous junction - High lying prostate → On IVP- Pie in-sky appearance

Management
  • Initial Management: Suprapubic catheterisation for urinary diversion
  • Delayed Urethroplasty (Definitive management): 3-6 months post-injury after inflammation and fibrosis have subsided (Option B ruled out)
  • Primary Realignment: Occasionally attempted if conditions permit
  • Endoscopic Realignment: For selected cases, though often reserved for acute management

Complications
  • Urethral stricture (most common long-term complication)
  • Urinary incontinence (due to sphincter damage)
  • Erectile dysfunction (common due to injury near neurovascular structures)
  • Bladder neck contracture
  • Chronic pelvic syndrome

questions.text: What is the cause of the following appearance in IVP?
questions.explanation:
Ureterocoele

Types
  • Simple Ureterocele (Intravesical - 20%): Found entirely within the bladder and associated with a single ureter. It is less complex and easier to manage.
  • Ectopic Ureterocele (80%): Extends beyond the bladder and often involves a duplicated ureter. This is more complicated due to its location, which may involve the bladder, neck, or urethra.

Etiology

Congenital anomaly is caused by an obstruction in the development of the distal ureter during fetal growth, leading to cystic dilation at the ureteral orifice.

Clinical Features
  • Recurrent Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)/ Urosepsis.
  • Unilateral Hydroureteronephrosis.
  • Palpable Abdominal Mass: Particularly in children, where a distended bladder or large ureterocele might be felt as a mass.

Investigations
  • Ultrasound (USG): The first-line imaging modality revealing hydroureteronephrosis and a cystic structure in the bladder.
  • Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU): Demonstrates a filling defect in the bladder caused by the ureterocele.
  • Cystoscopy: Allows direct visualisation of the ureterocele as a cystic structure that enlarges and collapses with urine flow in the bladder.
  • Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP): The investigation of choice (IOC) for diagnosing ureterocele, showing the characteristic "adder head" or "cobra head" appearance due to the dilated ureter within the bladder.

 

Cobra head or adder head appearance

Treatment

The treatment approach depends on the type of ureterocele:

  • Intravesical Ureterocele: Typically managed with an incision over the cyst wall to allow free flow of urine into the bladder, relieving the obstruction.
  • Ectopic Ureterocele: More complex, often requiring surgical excision of the ureterocele and reimplantation of the ureter into the bladder to correct the abnormal anatomy.

Associated Congenital Abnormalities
  • The most common congenital abnormality of the upper urinary tract is ureteral duplication, which can be associated with ureterocele.
  • Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR), another common congenital abnormality, may occur in conjunction with ureterocele, particularly in cases involving ureteral duplication.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man developed abdominal pain for which he was being evaluated. You notice the following in his CECT. What is the likely condition indicated by the arrow in the image?
questions.explanation:
Horseshoe kidney

Causes
  • During fetal development, the kidneys fuse at their lower poles, forming a U-shaped structure.
  • This fusion results in the inferior mesenteric artery preventing the ascent of the isthmus of the kidney to its normal position in the abdomen, leading to an abnormal location lower in the abdomen.

Clinical features
  • Mostly asymptomatic.
  • Pain: due to obstruction or renal stones.
  • Recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs).
  • Hydronephrosis.
  • Hematuria
  • Rovsing's syndrome: Hyperextension of the spine- nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain.

Investigations
  • CT Angiography (CT Angio): This is the investigation of choice for diagnosing a horseshoe kidney, as it allows for detailed visualisation of the renal anatomy, the abnormal vascular supply, and associated complications.
  • Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT): Used when CT Angio is not available
  • Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) - characteristic findings include:
    • Medial Orientation of Calyces: Referred to as the "Hand Joining Sign."

High Insertion of Ureters with Anterior Transposition: This creates a "Flower Vase" appearance of the ureters.

 

 

Treatment

Treatment depends on the presence and severity of symptoms:

  • Asymptomatic Patients: Typically do not require treatment but should be monitored periodically.
  • Symptomatic Patients:
    • UPJ Obstruction: Surgical intervention such as pyeloplasty
    • Kidney Stones: Management may include conservative measures like increased fluid intake, medical therapy, or surgical removal
    • UTIs: Treated with antibiotics, and preventive measures may be considered if infections are recurrent.
    • Isthmus Management: The isthmus of the horseshoe kidney should not be divided surgically as it contains functional renal tissue.
    • Pregnancy Considerations: A horseshoe kidney can lead to dystocia (difficult labour) due to the kidney's abnormal position.
