questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a patient who visited the outpatient department (OPD) experiencing intense pain during erection and a deviated penis for the past half-year?
questions.explanation:
Peyronie’s disease

Definition

It is characterised by fibrous plaques in the tunica albuginea of the penis, causing abnormal curvature during erections.

Characteristics

Plaque Location: Typically on the dorsolateral aspect of the penis.

Curvature: Resulting from plaque contraction.

 

Causes
  • Trauma/Injury: Repeated minor trauma to the penis.
  • Genetic Factors: Possible genetic predisposition.
  • Connective Tissue Disorders: Associated with conditions like Dupuytren’s contracture.

Associated Conditions

Galezia’s Triad:

  • Dupuytren’s Contracture: Thickening and shortening of connective tissue in fingers.
  • Retroperitoneal Fibrosis: Fibrosis in the retroperitoneal space.
  • Peyronie’s Disease

Clinical Features
  • Painful Erection
  • Erectile Dysfunction
  • Penile Curvature
  • Palpable Plaques
  • Impotence & Infertility (in severe cases)

Treatment

Observation:

  • Spontaneous Resolution: Often improves without treatment.

Medical Management:

  • Oral Medications: Pentoxifylline, colchicine, vitamin E (efficacy varies).

Surgical Intervention (If Spontaneous Resolution Does Not Occur):

  • Nesbit Operation: Placement of a non-absorbable suture opposite the plaque to correct the curvature.
  • Plication Surgery: Shortens the longer side of the penis.
  • Plaque Excision and Grafting: Removes plaque and replaces it with graft material.
  • Penile Prosthesis: For severe cases.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a 5-year-old boy who has weight loss, fever, and a painless swelling in his jaw area? CBC results indicate anaemia and lymphocytosis. The image below shows biopsy findings from the swelling.
questions.explanation:
Burkitt's lymphoma

Aspects

Description

Definition

An aggressive form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterised by the proliferation of mature B-cells.

Epidemiology
  • Endemic (African) form: Common in children, associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection.
  • Sporadic form: Worldwide distribution, more common in children and young adults.
  • Immunodeficiency-related: Often seen in HIV/AIDS patients.

Etiology
  • Strong association with EBV (especially in the endemic form).
  • Translocations involving the MYC gene (chromosome 8).

Genetic Abnormality
  • t(8;14): MYC gene translocated next to the IgH locus (most common).
  • t(2;8) or t(8;22): Less common, involving MYC and Ig light chain loci.

Clinical Features
  • Endemic form: Presents with jaw or facial bone tumours.
  • Sporadic form: Often involves the abdomen (e.g., ileum, cecum) and may cause bowel obstruction.
  • Systemic symptoms: Fever, night sweats, weight loss.

Pathology
  • Histology: "Starry-sky" appearance due to numerous apoptotic cells and macrophages.
  • Tumor cells are medium-sized with round nuclei, coarse chromatin, and high mitotic activity.

Immunophenotype
  • Positive for CD19, CD20 (B-cell markers), and CD10.
  • Expresses surface IgM.
  • High proliferation index (Ki-67 > 95%).

Diagnosis
  • Biopsy: Histological examination showing "starry-sky" appearance.
  • Cytogenetics: Detection of MYC translocations.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Positive for B-cell markers (CD19, CD20).

Prognosis
  • Highly aggressive but potentially curable with prompt treatment.
  • Favorable response to chemotherapy in many cases.

Treatment
  • Chemotherapy: Intensive regimens like cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and methotrexate (CODOX-M).
  • CNS prophylaxis: Methotrexate or cytarabine.
  • Supportive care for tumour lysis syndrome.

Complications
  • Risk of tumour lysis syndrome due to rapid tumour breakdown.
  • It may progress to involve bone marrow or CNS if untreated.

Differential Diagnosis
  • Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.
  • Other high-grade B-cell lymphomas.
  • Lymphoblastic lymphoma.
  • Hodgkin lymphoma (rarely resembles).

questions.text: Graft from an identical twin is called:
questions.explanation:
Type of Graft

Description

Autograft

An organ or tissue is taken from an individual and grafted on him/ herself

(Option B ruled out)

Isograft

Grafts between genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins

(Option C)

Allograft

Graft between two genetically non-identical members of the same species (e.g. organ transplants between two non-identical and compatible individuals. (Option A ruled out)

Xenograft

Graft from one species to another (e.g., pig skin is a temporary substitute for burn treatment). (Option D ruled out)

Synthetic Graft

Artificial materials or bioengineered constructs replace or support damaged tissue (e.g., artificial skin substitutes, bone graft substitutes).

questions.text: A neonate presented with mild intermittent upper abdominal pain. On examination, the infant has a scaphoid abdomen and breath sounds are decreased on both sides. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:

Aspect

Description

It is due to the failure of the fusion of the pleuroperitoneal canal, which leads to direct communication between the pleura and peritoneum on the left side.

Contents

Colon, occasionally small bowel or stomach

Associated Conditions
  • Hypoplasia (potentially bilateral)
  • Decreased bronchial branch generation
  • Extension of tunica media beyond respiratory bronchioles
  • Decreased total lung mass

Diagnostic Features

  • Pulmonary hypertension

Clinical Features

  • Scaphoid abdomen
  • Bowel sounds on the left side of the chest
  • Mediastinal shift towards the right side
  • Intestinal obstruction

questions.text: What is the term for a stone obstructing the cystic duct, causing dilation of the common hepatic duct, resulting in CBD obstruction and jaundice?
questions.explanation:
Mirizzi’s syndrome

Pathophysiology
  • The gallstone usually impacts from the Hartmann's pouch, leading to compression of the CHD/CBD.
  • Can also occur from the fundus of the gallbladder into the CBD.

Clinical features
  • Fever
  • Abdominal pain
  • Obstructive jaundice
  • Upper abdominal tenderness on the right side
  • Possible palpable soft, enlarged liver

Csendes Classification

Type I - Extrinsic compression of the CBD/CHD by a large impacted stone in Hartmann's pouch;

  • IA- the presence of cystic duct
  • IB- is obliterated cystic duct

Type II - The stone has eroded the CBD/CHD less than 1/3rd of the circumference of the CBD/CHD, forming a fistula

Type III - Involving up to 2/3rd of the circumference of CBD/ CHD

Type IV - Cholecystocholedochal fistula (>2/3rd) involving the entire circumference of the CBD/CHD

Type V - Cholecystocholedochal fistula with cholecystoenteric fistula without gallstone ileus (VA) or with

gallstone ileus (VB)

Investigations
  • Ultrasonography (USG): Initial imaging to assess gallbladder and ducts.
  • CT Scan: Provides detailed imaging of the biliary system.
  • ERCP/ MRCP: Essential for delineating duct anatomy and identifying the site of obstruction.
  • HIDA Scan: Useful for functional assessment of the biliary system.
  • Findings: Dilatation of the intrahepatic biliary system with a block at the common hepatic duct (CHD).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the OPD with a history of a lump in the left breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump in the left breast is 9x10 cm with the following appearance and no axillary lymphadenopathy. The histopathology of the biopsy from the lump shows increased stromal cellularity and typical leaflike architecture. What is your likely diagnosis?

A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distention. On investigations, hepatosplenomegaly and malar eminence are seen, and his peripheral blood smear is shown below. He has a low Hb; the Mentzer index is less than 13. What diagnosis would this signify for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Thalassemia Major (β-Thalassemia Major)

Features

Description

Definition

A severe form of β-thalassemia caused by homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the β-globin gene (HBB) on chromosome 11, leading to absent or markedly reduced β-globin chain production.

Genetics

Autosomal recessive disorder, caused by mutations in the β-globin gene leading to defective hemoglobin synthesis.

Pathophysiology

Reduced or absent β-globin chains lead to excess α-globin chains, which form unstable precipitates, causing ineffective erythropoiesis, hemolysis, and severe anaemia.

Clinical Features

Symptoms appear around 6 months of age (as fetal haemoglobin declines); severe anaemia, growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, skeletal deformities (crew-cut appearance on skull X-ray, frontal bossing), jaundice, and delayed puberty.

Hematological Findings
  • Peripheral smear: Microcytic hypochromic anaemia, target cells, anisopoikilocytosis, nucleated RBCs.
  • Bone marrow: Erythroid hyperplasia with expansion of marrow cavities.

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis

Absent or very low HbA, markedly increased HbF (>90%), variable HbA2.

Complications
  • Iron overload (due to repeated transfusions leading to secondary hemochromatosis)
  • Cardiac failure (due to iron deposition)
  • Endocrinopathies (diabetes, hypothyroidism, hypogonadism)
  • Osteopenia/osteoporosis
  • Increased infection risk (especially from Yersinia and viral infections).

Diagnosis

Blood tests (CBC, peripheral smear), Hb electrophoresis/HPLC, Serum ferritin (for iron overload), Genetic testing (HBB gene mutations), Prenatal diagnosis (chorionic villus sampling or amniocentesis).

Treatment

Regular blood transfusions, iron chelation therapy (deferoxamine, deferasirox, deferiprone), splenectomy (in refractory cases), and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) (only curative option).

Prevention

Carrier screening, genetic counselling, prenatal diagnosis, preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD) in high-risk couples.

Feature

 

Iron Deficiency Anemia

Beta Thalassemia Minor

 

Type

Microcytic hypochromic anemia

Microcytic hypochromic anemia

RBC

Less

More

MCV

Normal to low

Low

RDW(size variance)

More

Normal

Mentzer index: MCV/RBC

>13

<13

Reticulocyte count

Low

Normal to slightly increased

HbA2 - confirmatory test

<3.5%

>3.5%

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a neonate who is brought to the hospital with complaints of forceful vomiting that is not accompanied by bile after feeding? The child appears lethargic and dehydrated, and abdominal examination shows visible movements of the stomach. A barium meal was conducted, and the image provided is shown below.
questions.explanation:
Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS)

Definition

It is a condition involving hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction in male infants, typically between 2 and 6 weeks of age.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeds, starting around 2 to 6 weeks of age.
    • Persistent vomiting leads to dehydration, hypokalemia and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis because the body loses hydrochloric acid (HCl) in the vomitus.
  • Physical Examination: Visible gastric peristalsis from left to right and a palpable “olive-shaped” mass in the epigastric region.

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasound (USG) is the Investigation of choice for CHPS, characterised by
    • Pyloric muscle thickness of > 3 mm
    • Pyloric length > 14 mm
    • The pyloric channel appears elongated and thickened (10-14 mm)

  • Contrast Studies (Upper GI Series): Less frequently used, demonstrating the classic ¸ with a thin line of contrast through the elongated and narrowed pyloric channel and delayed gastric emptying without duodenal dilation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with anaemia and hepatosplenomegaly. A peripheral smear showed teardrop cells, nucleated RBCs, and giant abnormal platelets. A biopsy showed marrow fibrosis and a few characteristics, as given below. The most likely diagnosis is:
A teenager developed swelling of the face, lips, and tongue and also found it difficult to breathe within a few minutes of consuming prawns. What type of hypersensitivity is seen here?
questions.explanation:
Type

Mechanism

Immune Components

Features

Examples

Type I: Immediate

(Option A)

IgE-mediated degranulation of mast cells and basophils after allergen binding.
  • IgE antibodies
  • Mast cells
  • Histamine
  • Rapid onset (minutes)
  • Localised or systemic reactions
  • Mediated by histamine.
  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergic rhinitis
  • Asthma
  • Urticaria (hives)
  • Food allergies

Type II: Cytotoxic

(Option B ruled out)

Antibody-mediated destruction or dysfunction of target cells.
  • IgG, IgM antibodies
  • Complement
  • Phagocytes
  • Targets specific cells or tissues.
  • Cell lysis or dysfunction.
  • Involves complement activation.
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome
  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Graves' disease

Type III: Immune Complex

(Option C ruled out)

Deposition of immune complexes in tissues, leading to inflammation and damage.
  • IgG, IgM Antibodies
  • Complement
  • Neutrophils
  • Immune complex deposition in vessels.
  • Tissue inflammation and damage (vasculitis).
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Serum sickness

Type IV: Delayed

(Option D ruled out)

T-cell-mediated immune response, leading to inflammation and tissue damage.
  • T cells (CD4+, CD8+)
  • Macrophages
  • Delayed onset (48–72 hours).
  • Involves cytokine release and macrophage recruitment.
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Tuberculin skin test (PPD)
  • Granulomatous inflammation (e.g., tuberculosis)

questions.text: Tau protein inclusions are involved in:
questions.explanation:
Plaques
  • Deposits of Aβ peptides in the neuropil.
  • They are of two types: Diffuse and neuritic (senile).
  • Neuritic plaques contain both Aβ 40 and Aβ 42.
  • Diffuse plaques are predominantly made up of Aβ 42 and seen in trisomy 21 patients.

Tangles
  • Aggregates of the microtubule-binding protein tau.
  • Demonstrated by silver (Bielschowsky) staining.
  • Commonly found in cortical neurons, especially in the entorhinal cortex, and in other sites such as pyramidal cells of the hippocampus, amygdala, basal forebrain, and raphe nuclei.

Hirano bodies
  • Intracellular eosinophilic inclusions are typically found in conditions like Alzheimer's disease and Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease.

Granulovacuolar degeneration
  • Formation of small, clear vacuoles within the neurons.

Plaques

Neurofibrillary tangles

Hirano bodies

Granulovacuolar degeneration

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient undergoes TURP, and after 3 days, the patient develops altered sensitiveness and drowsiness. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
TURP Syndrome

Pathophysiology

It is because fluid is absorbed intravascularly due to high volumes of hypotonic irrigation fluid used during the resection, causing dilutional hyponatremia and various neurologic symptoms.

Risk factors
  • Size of prostate > 75g
  • Duration of surgery > 90 minutes
  • Pre-existing hyponatremia
  • Renal failure

Clinical presentation
  • Confusion,
  • Agitation,
  • Nervousness,
  • Nausea,
  • Hemolysis,
  • Visual disturbances,
  • Coma and shock.

Treatment
  • Drug of choice: IV furosemide.
  • Mild to moderate cases: IV furosemide and normal saline
  • Severe or symptomatic patients: IV 3% Saline
  • Fluid restriction: Useful after initial stabilisation and correction of severe hyponatremia to prevent further fluid overload.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman had her routine follow-up, and her USG of the liver is shown below. She is asymptomatic at present but has a history of mild right hypochondriac pain, which is relieved by taking analgesics. What is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the preferred management of the condition in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Angular Dermoid

Presentation

It commonly occurs as a smooth, non-tender, soft swelling at the fronto-zygomatic suture.

Location

They are most often located near the lateral canthus, which is the outer corner of the eye where the upper and lower eyelids meet. They may also occur near suture lines of the skull.

Symptoms

They are usually asymptomatic unless they become large enough to cause pressure effects on adjacent structures or become infected.

Diagnosis

Ultrasound or CT scans may be used to evaluate the extent of the cyst, especially if deep or orbital involvement is suspected.

Management

(Option A)

Surgical Excision: Complete surgical excision is the treatment of choice, especially if the cyst is causing cosmetic concerns or other symptoms.

  • Careful dissection is required to ensure the cyst is fully removed and avoid recurrence.
  • If left untreated, angular dermoids sometimes undergo resorption or indentation of the underlying base. CT is done to rule out dural attachments.

Causes
  • Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis.
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Crohn’s disease
    • Tuberculosis
    • Lymphogranuloma venereum
    • Actinomycosis
    • Rectal duplication
    • Foreign bodies
    • Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula)

Clinical features
  • Intermittent purulent discharge: This may be bloody and purulent. Discomfort typically increases until the pus discharges, providing temporary relief.
  • Previous history of Anorectal abscess
  • Passage of flatus or faeces: Through the external opening (indicative of a rectal rather than an anal internal opening).

Parks classification

Type 1 - Inter- sphincteric (most common, 70%)

Type 2 - Trans- sphincteric (25%)

Type 3 - Supra- sphincteric (4%)

Type 4 - Extra- sphincteric (1%)

Details

Indications

Neurological conditions (e.g., spinal cord injury)

Procedure

Incision made below vocal cords, tube inserted into trachea.

Tube Types

questions.text: A patient, after heavy drinking of alcohol presents with multiple episodes of vomiting and hematemesis. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Mallory-Weiss syndrome

Definition

It is defined as mucosal lacerations in the gastric mucosa at the gastroesophageal (GE) junction that are caused by forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or straining.

Epidemiology
  • It accounts for 10-15% of acute upper gastrointestinal haemorrhages.
  • The greatest risk for massive haemorrhage is alcoholic patients with preexisting portal hypertension.

Risk Factors
  • Alcoholic patients with intense vomiting after binge drinking.
  • Forceful abdominal contractions against a closed cardia.
  • Any patient with repeated episodes of emesis.
  • Portal hypertension in alcoholic patients.

Diagnosis
  • The patient's history is crucial.
  • It can be confirmed with endoscopy.
  • Retroflexion manoeuvre during endoscopy is used to view the area below the gastroesophageal junction.

Symptoms

Vomiting, hematemesis, upper abdominal pain, hypotension, tachycardia

Complications

Rarely massive bleeding associated with portal hypertension

Treatment

Endoscopic methods (multipolar electrocoagulation, epinephrine injection, band ligation), angiographic transarterial embolisation, rarely surgery

Prognosis

Generally good with appropriate endoscopic treatment

questions.text: Auspitz sign is seen in?
Which type of cells are implicated in the development of contact dermatitis in a 12-year-old boy who presented to the emergency department?
questions.explanation:
Mechanisms of Type IV hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Cytokine-mediated inflammation
(mediated by CD4+ T cells)
  • CD4+ T cells recognise protein antigens presented by APCs and differentiate into Th1 and Th17 cells.
  • Th1 cells secrete cytokines like IFN-γ, activating macrophages to cause tissue damage and fibrosis.
  • Th17 cells produce IL-17 to recruit neutrophils, promoting inflammation.
  • Tuberculin test (a classic example of delayed-type hypersensitivity)
  • Granulomas
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • IBD
  • Psoriasis

T cell-mediated cytotoxicity (mediated by CD8+ T cells)

 

 
  • Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill antigen-bearing target cells, including tumour cells, virus-infected cells, and allogeneic tissue, during graft rejection.
  • CTLs use perforin-granzyme-dependent killing and Fas-Fas ligand-dependent killing mechanisms to induce apoptosis in target cells.
  • Type 1 DM
  • Hepatic injury in HBV infection
  • Graft vs host disease

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy came to the emergency room with the following X-ray. On examination, he had a sensory loss in the lateral arm and sensory loss in the posterior aspect of the forearm. Which of the following is true about his condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Humerus shaft fracture with radial nerve palsy

questions.correct_answer: D. Humerus shaft fracture with radial nerve palsy
questions.explanation:
Nerve

Root origin

Common causes

Features

Radial

C5-T1
  • Compression in axilla (crutches, "Saturday night palsy")
  • Midshaft fracture of humerus
  • Repetitive pronation/supination (screwdriver use, "finger drop")

Above elbow injury:

  • Loss of sensation over posterior arm/forearm and dorsal hand
  • Wrist drop (loss of elbow, wrist, and finger extension)
  • Decreased grip strength (wrist extension necessary for maximal action of flexors)

Below elbow injury:

  • Distal paresthesias without wrist drop

Midshaft fracture:

  • Tricep function and posterior arm sensation spared

Median

C5-T1
  • Supracondylar fracture of humerus (proximal lesion)
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome and wrist laceration (distal lesion)
  • "Ape hand" and "Hand of benediction"
  • Loss of wrist flexion
  • Loss of function of LOAF muscles (Lumbricals (lateral two), Opponens pollicis, Abductor pollicis brevis, Flexor pollicis brevis)
  • Loss of sensation over thenar eminence and dorsal and palmar aspects of lateral 3 1/2 fingers with proximal lesion

Ulnar

C8-T1
  • Fracture of medial epicondyle of humerus (proximal lesion)
  • Fractured hook of hamate (distal lesion) from fall on outstretched hand
  • Compression of nerve against hamate during cycling
  • "Ulnar claw" on digit extension
  • Radial deviation of wrist upon flexion (proximal lesion)
  • Decreased flexion of ulnar fingers
  • Loss of abduction and adduction of fingers (interossei)
  • Loss of thumb adduction
  • Loss of action of ulnar 2 lumbrical muscles
  • Loss of sensation over ulnar 1 1/2 fingers including hypothenar eminence

Ulnar

C8-T1

questions.text: Specific sign of kwashiorkor is:
questions.explanation:
Features of Kwashiorkar and Marasmus

Kwashiorkor

Marasmus

Pitting Edema: Specific sign of Kwashiorkar Characterized by swelling, often starting in the legs and feet, leaving a persistent indentation when pressed.

Severe Wasting: The child appears extremely thin, with prominent bones and little body fat.

Sugar Baby Appearance: The child may look deceptively healthy due to oedema, despite being malnourished.

Monkey Facies: A sunken appearance of the cheeks due to loss of fat, giving an aged look.

Muscle Wasting: Despite the swollen appearance, muscle loss is present, leading to weakness and hypotonia.

Baggy Pants Appearance: Loose, sagging skin around the buttocks caused by significant muscle and fat loss.

Mental and Neurological Symptoms: The child is apathetic, irritable, and may have feeding difficulties.

Alertness: Children with marasmus remain mentally alert.

Hair Changes: Hair may lose colour, become thin, and show alternating bands of colour ("flag sign").

Absence of Edema: Unlike kwashiorkor, marasmus does not involve swelling or oedema.

Skin Changes: Includes hyperpigmentation, peeling skin ("flaky paint" appearance), and colour changes, particularly in the buttocks, perineum, and thighs.

Hypoglycemia Risk: The liver's reduced capacity to produce glucose increases the risk of low blood sugar.
Gastrointestinal Issues: Anorexia, vomiting, and abdominal distension. Anaemia is present due to nutritional deficiencies. Hypothermia Risk: The child may struggle to maintain body temperature due to energy depletion.

A 3-year-old boy who presents with repetitive episodes of urinary tract infection. The mother reports that he urinates frequently but has a weak urinary flow and dribbling of urine. Upon examination, a palpable bladder is detected. What is the most sensitive investigation that can be employed to determine the underlying diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR)

Definition

Retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to ureters and pelvis at rest or during micturition

Epidemiology
  • Present in 30-35% of children with febrile UTI
  • Conventionally considered a major risk factor for acute pyelonephritis and reflux nephropathy
  • Can cause morbidity during pregnancy

Diagnostic Methods

Primary Methods:

  • Radionuclide MCU (more sensitive for detecting VUR)
  • Direct or indirect radionuclide cystography
  • Regular radiologic imaging every 24-36 months for grades III-IV VUR

Additional Techniques:

  • Contrast-enhanced ultrasound
  • MR urography
  • Urinalysis and urine cultures (if symptomatic)

Follow-up Monitoring:

  • Weight and blood pressure measurements
  • Periodic radiologic cystogram

Prophylactic Antibiotics

Medications and Dosages:

  • Amoxiciilin: 10-12.5 mg/kg/day
  • Nitrofurantoin: 1-2 mg/kg/day
  • Cephalexin: 10-12.5 mg/kg/day
  • Cefadroxil: 5 mg/kg/day

Special Considerations:

  • Avoid cotrimoxazole in infants <3 months, and those with G6PD deficiency
  • Avoid nitrofurantoin in <3 months, G6PD deficiency, renal insufficiency
  • Cephalexin is the drug of choice in the first 3-6 months of life
  • Cefadroxil is an alternative agent in early infancy

Management Approach

For Low Grade VUR (I-II):

  • With UTI: Consider antibiotic prophylaxis and Bladder-Bowel dysfunction management
  • Without UTI: No therapy needed

For High Grade VUR (III-IV):

  • With BBD: Antibiotic prophylaxis until BBD resolves, manage BBD
  • Without BBD: Antibiotic prophylaxis until age 2 and >1-yr UTI-free

Additional Considerations:

  • Medical therapy based on the principle that VUR resolves over time
  • Prophylactic antibiotics maintain sterile urine and prevent UTI while awaiting resolution
  • Surgical correction indicated for breakthrough infections or parenchymal injury

Treatment Guidelines
  • Consider dietary modification and medications
  • Some patients require bladder retraining, anticholinergic medications
  • Clean intermittent catheterization may be needed
  • Liberal fluid intake recommended
  • Regular and complete bladder emptying is important
  • Avoid constipation
  • Close follow-up for breakthrough UTI

Outcomes
  • Tends to resolve by 10 years of age
  • Resolution rate 70-90% for grades I-III
  • 10-35% resolution for higher grades
  • Better outcomes with: younger age, lower grades, unilateral VUR

A 55 year old male patient presented with complaints of dyspnea with congestive heart failure. The clinician wants to know whether it's HF with preserved EF or reduced EF. Which of the below investigation is used for calculation of ejection fraction?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A- MUGA

 

Purpose

Scan types

For Myocardial Perfusion

  • Assess ischemia
  • Cold spot: decreased uptake in ischemic areas.
  • Thallium scan (Commonly used) (Option B)
  • Tetrofosmin
  • Sestamibi scan (Option D)

For Myocardial Infarction

  • Assess infarct
  • Hot spot in infarct area as pyrophosphate accumulates and is not metabolized.
  • 99m Tc - Pyrophosphate scan.

For Ventricular Function

  • Evaluate ejection fraction
  • MUGA (Multiple Gated Acquisition) scan (AKA nuclear ventriculography)
    • Radiolabeled RBCs are used
  • Most accurate for ventricular function - Cardiac MRI

For Myocardial Viability

 
  • Assess the viability of myocardium
  • PETscan - Best investigation for myocardial viability. (Option C)
    • Perfusion and metabolism mismatch are observed in the PET scan.
    • Perfusion Agents:N-13 ammonia and Rubidium chloride.
    • Metabolism Agent:
    • FDG-PET is used for glucose metabolism.
      • No FDG uptake indicates a normal heart or an infarct.
      • FDG uptake is present: In the Ischemic Myocardium
    • FDG-PET is combined with perfusion imaging for comprehensive assessment.
      • Uptake in PET with low perfusion indicates reversible dysfunction (suggestive of hibernation).
      • Irreversible dysfunction indicates the presence of scar tissue.
    • Note: Hibernating myocardium is ischemic but viable.

questions.text: During the surgery for acute appendicitis in a 2-year-old child, the surgeon discovered a structure measuring 2 inches in length located 2 feet closer to the ileocecal junction. What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Meckel Diverticulum:

Most common congenital GI anomaly (2-3% of infants) with incomplete obliteration of omphalomesenteric duct.

Characteristics ("Rule of 2s")
  • 2% of population
  • 2 feet from the ileocecal valve
  • 2 inches long
  • 2 types of ectopic tissue (gastric or pancreatic)
  • Often presents before age 2
  • 2 times more common in males

Clinical Manifestations
  • Painless rectal bleeding (most common)
  • Bowel obstruction
  • Diverticulitis

Diagnosis
  • Meckel scan (technetium-99m pertechnetate)
    • Sensitivity: 85%
    • Specificity: 95%
    • Used to diagnose ectopic gastric mucosa
  • Plain radiographs and barium studies are less useful

Complications

Intussusception, Volvulus and Perforation.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a newborn who has a liver and small intestine protruding through the umbilicus, covered by membranes at birth?
questions.explanation:
Gastroschisis (Option B)

Omphalocele (Option A)

Definition

A congenital defect where the abdominal wall fails to close, leading to herniation of intestinal loops into the amniotic cavity.

M/c in premature/SGA babies

A congenital ventral body wall defect where portions of the midgut fail to return to the abdominal cavity after physiological herniation.

Location of defect

Right paraumbilical

Central

Sac

Absent, bowel is exposed.

Present (if not ruptured).

Sac is made of amnion, Wharton's jelly and peritoneum

Description

Free intestinal loops.

(Liver is not usually herniated)

Firm mass including liver, intestine and/ other organs (like stomach, spleen)

Umbilical cord

Adjacent to the defect

Attached to the sac

Associated anomalies

Associated anatomic defects are uncommon

Associated abnormalities are common and include:

  • Neural tube defect
  • Cardiac abnormalities
  • Chromosomal defect

Detection

  • Identified through fetal ultrasound.
  • Elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels in maternal serum and amniotic fluid.

Elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) concentrations in maternal serum and amniotic fluid, similar to gastroschisis.

Complication

  • Affected bowel loops may be damaged due to exposure to corrosive amniotic fluid.
  • Risk of volvulus, where the bowel twists around itself, compromising blood supply.
  • Feeding difficulties
  • Failure to thrive
  • Inguinal hernias
  • Gastroesophageal reflux
  • Occasionally esophagitis

Prognosis

Favorable

High mortality rates

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a patient who has chronic small bowel diarrhea, claims to have a wheat allergy, and exhibits villous atrophy on duodenal biopsy with tests positive for anti-endomysial antibodies and tissue transglutaminase (TTG) IgA antibodies?
questions.explanation:
Celiac sprue / Celiac disease / Gluten-sensitive enteropathy

Clinical manifestations
  • Diarrhoea, growth failure, and anaemia.
  • Temporal association with the introduction of wheat products at weaning.
  • Abdominal distension, vomiting, anorexia, aphthous stomatitis, and bloating.
  • Rickets, osteoporosis, short stature, muscular atrophy, peripheral neuropathy, and irritability might be seen in some cases.
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis can be seen.

Diagnosis:

ESPGHAN (European Society for Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology & Nutrition) guidelines 2020 suggest that in all suspected cases (symptomatic, asymptomatic, and at-risk group), the first test should be total serum IgA and IgAtTG.

 

Serology:

  • Anti-TTG (Tissue Transglutaminase)
  • Anti EMA (Endomysial antibody)
  • Anti-DGP (Deamidated gliadin peptide)

 

Upper GI endoscopy:

  • The endoscopy may be normal or show the absence of folds or scalloped duodenal folds.

 

Histopathology:

  • Villous atrophy/Flat villi
  • Crypt hyperplasia
  • Intraepithelial lymphocyte infiltration.

Treatment:
  • Treatment involves a gluten-free diet (avoid wheat, rye, barley and oats).
  • High-risk groups include type 1 diabetes mellitus, Down syndrome, selective IgA deficiency, autoimmune thyroid disease, Turner syndrome, Williams syndrome, Addison’s disease, autoimmune liver disease and first-degree relatives of patients with celiac disease.
  • A temporal association may be present with the introduction of wheat products at weaning.

questions.text: Under which benefit in the ESI act do beneficiaries receive 70% of their wages for a duration of 3 months?
questions.explanation:
Benefits of ESI (Employees State Insurance) Act

Medical Benefit (Option B ruled out)
  • Provides "full medical care," including hospitalization at no cost to insured individuals & families in cases of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.

Sickness Benefit (Option A)
  • Provides 70% of average daily wages in cash during medical leave for a maximum of 91 days within 365 days, as certified by the Insurance Medical Officer/Practitioner.

Extended Sickness Benefit
  • Extended coverage for long-term diseases beyond 91 days; 34 diseases covered if employed for two years.
  • Extended sickness benefit is paid at 80% of the insured person's wages.

Enhanced Sickness Benefit
  • Cash benefits (100% wages) for sterilization procedures:
    • 14 days for tubectomy (women),
    • 7 days for vasectomy (men).

Maternity Benefit (Option C ruled out)

 
  • Cash payments for childbirth, miscarriage, or pregnancy-related sickness:
    • 26 weeks for childbirth,
    • 6 weeks for miscarriage, and
    • 40 days for pregnancy-related sickness.
  • Paid at 100% of the insured woman's average daily wages.

Disablement Benefit

 
  • Temporary Disablement Benefit (TDB):
    • 90% of wages paid from day one for temporary employment injury, until recovery.
  • Permanent Disablement Benefit (PDB):
    • 90% of wages paid monthly for life, based on certified loss of earning capacity.

Dependent's Benefit (Option D ruled out)
  • Dependents receive 90% of the deceased's (due to employment injuries) wages as a shared pension, and they are eligible until age 18.
  • If the daughter marries before 18, the benefit is withdrawn.

Funeral Expenses
  • It offers a cash payment of up to Rs. 15,000 to cover funeral expenses upon the death of an insured individual.

Rehabilitation

 
  • Insured individuals and their families are entitled to continued medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.
  • They have to pay a nominal fee of Rs.10 per month for this benefit.
  • A rehabilitation allowance of Rs.15,000 granted.

Unemployment allowance
  • For eligible employees due to factory closure or retrenchment: 50% of wage for up to two years.

questions.text: A 23-year-old G3 P1L1 A1 at 37 weeks of gestation with a previous history of emergency caesarean section and dilatation and curettage presents to the ER with labor pains. During abdominal examination, it was difficult to palpate fetal parts. Per vaginal examination revealed a 5 cm dilated cervix, and her vitals were: BP-80/60 mmHg, RR – 20/min, HR – 106/min, SpO2 – 97% on room air. CTG showed a non-reassuring variable fetal heart rate pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Revealed

  • Most common type, where the bleeding from the placental detachment is visible and exits through the vagina.
  • This is often associated with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain.

Concealed

  • Bleeding is hidden behind the placenta and is not visible externally.
  • Blood collects within the uterus, causing increased pressure and pain without visible bleeding.

Mixed

  • Involves both concealed and revealed bleeding.
  • There is both internal and external bleeding, with some blood exiting through the vagina and some collecting behind the placenta.

Grade

Maternal findings

Fetal findings

0
  • Clinical features may be absent.
  • The diagnosis is made after inspection of the placenta following delivery.

1

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness ±)

Fetal heart sounds are normal

2

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness always +)

Fetal distress

3

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain (marked uterine tenderness) + Shock ± Coagulopathy

Fetal death

 

Placenta previa

Abruptio placentae

Clinical features

Nature of bleeding

Painless, causeless, and recurrent.

Painful, often attributed to Pre-eclampsia or trauma, and continuous.

Character of blood

Bleeding is always revealed.

Revealed, concealed, or usually mixed.

General condition & anaemia

Proportionate to visible blood loss.

Out of proportion to the visible blood loss in the concealed or mixed variety.

Features of eclampsia

Not relevant.

Present in one-third of the cases.

Abdominal examination

Height of the uterus

Proportionate height to the gestational age.

It may be disproportionately enlarged in concealed type.

The feel of the uterus

Soft and relaxed.

It may be tense, tender, and rigid.

Malpresentation

Common (the head is high floating).

Unrelated, the head may be engaged.

Fetal heart sounds

Usually present.

Usually absent, especially in the concealed type.

USG, MRI

Placenta in the lower segment.

Placenta in the upper segment.

Vaginal examination

The placenta is felt on the lower segment (not to be done in a suspected case).

The placenta is not felt on the lower segment. Blood clots should not be confused with placenta.

questions.text: In a boarding school where students share the same canteen, one student experienced abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever. Subsequently, other students began showing similar symptoms. Which investigations should the local medical officer consider in order to arrive at a diagnosis?
A nurse got an accidental prick from a needle used for an HIV+ patient. Which single test would lead to a confirmatory diagnosis in her?
questions.explanation:
LABORATORY DIAGNOSIS OF HIV INFECTION

Screening tests

ELISA screens for HIV antibodies (most sensitive) (Option C ruled out)

Confirmatory tests
  • Western blot - A confirmatory test confirms specific antibodies against p24 and gp41 proteins. (highly specific) (Option D)
  • Confirmatory test for adults - qPCR for HIV1 (Option B ruled out)
  • Confirmatory tests of infants < 1 year - HIV DNA RT-PCR

Virus Isolation

Direct virus testing is not standard; HIV isolation from cultured lymphocytes is costly and resource-intensive.

CD4 Lymphocyte Count

Most reliable predictor of HIV progression; absolute count indicates immune system health, with <200 cells/µL signalling a high risk of AIDS-related infections.

CD4 Lymphocyte Percentage

Independent indicator of disease progression; <14% suggests a heightened risk of AIDS-related complications.

HIV Viral Load Tests

Measure actively replicating HIV in blood; correlate with disease progression and assess antiretroviral therapy effectiveness.

Other Markers

Parametric Test

Description

Paired Student's t-test

Used to compare means (± SD) in paired data from the same group of individuals before and after an intervention.

Unpaired Student's t-test (Option B)

Used to compare means (± SD) in two different groups of individuals. The Z-test is a variant of the unpaired Student's t-test used when the sample size is > 30.

ANOVA (Option A ruled out)

Used to compare means (± SD) in more than two different groups of individuals.

Pearson correlation coefficient

Measures the linear association between two variables and can range from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).

A 60-year-old woman comes with chronic vulval itching and pain. On examination, there is a vulval lesion suspicious of vulval cancer. Which of the following lymph node/s should be considered for sentinel node biopsy to look for the metastatic spread?
questions.explanation:
Age Group

Most common in elderly women, especially in the 6th and 7th decades, (50-70 years age group)

Risk Factors

HPV infections, HSV infections, smoking, chronic immunosuppression, chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., lichen sclerosis).

Histological Type

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common type.

Common Sites
  • Labia majora: Most common site (60%).
  • Clitoris: Second most common site (15%).

Presentation
  • Exophytic (outward-growing) growth.
  • Ulcerative lesions.

Symptoms
  • Pruritus (most common), often associated with an itch-scratch cycle.
  • Swelling, lump, or ulcer.
  • Cancer cachexia (weight loss and muscle wasting).
  • Cancer pain (late symptom).

Spread
  • Primarily through the lymphatic system.
  • Vulvar lymphatics cross midline, especially within 2 cm of the midline.
  • Commonly involved lymph nodes: Inguinofemoral.
  • Lymph node involvement significantly impacts prognosis.

Investigations
  • Excisional biopsy: Preferred for lesions < 1 cm, for histological assessment of invasion depth.
  • Incisional biopsy: For lesions ≥ 1 cm.
  • Wedge biopsy, Keyes punch biopsy, and sentinel lymph node biopsy (to assess inguinofemoral node involvement).

Treatment
  • Vulvectomy: Partial or total, depending on disease stage.
  • Inguinal lymph node dissection: To evaluate disease spread.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy (Superficial inguinal lymph nodes): Determines stage and prognosis.

questions.text: What are the potential long-term consequences of this condition in a 25-year-old female with a previous history of chlamydia infection who currently presents with mild fever, non-specific lower abdominal pain, mild diffuse tenderness upon deep palpation in the lower abdomen, cervical motion tenderness, and mucopurulent discharge from the vagina?
questions.explanation:
Pathogenesis

Infection ascends from the cervix and endometrium to the fallopian tubes and ovaries, causing inflammation and scarring. Can lead to infertility, ectopic pregnancy, and chronic pelvic pain.

Aetiology

Acute:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, E. coli, Mycoplasma genitalium, Anaerobes (Bacteroides species), Gardnerella vaginalis, Trichomonas vaginalis, Streptococci, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Actinomyces israelii.

 

Chronic: Same as acute, with possible additional mixed infections.

Clinical Features

Signs:

Fever, Purulent cervical discharge, Cervical motion tenderness, Adnexal tenderness, Abdominal tenderness.

 

Symptoms:

Lower abdominal pain, Abnormal vaginal discharge, Dyspareunia (pain during intercourse), Dysuria (pain during urination), Menstrual irregularities, Nausea and vomiting.

Complications
  • Infertility: Due to scarring and damage to fallopian tubes.
  • Ectopic Pregnancy
  • Chronic Pelvic Pain
  • Peritonitis
  • Sepsis

Laboratory Findings

Elevated WBC, Elevated CRP, Elevated ESR.

Ultrasound: Thickened, fluid-filled fallopian tubes and free pelvic fluid.

Next Step in Diagnosis

Endocervical Swab: Detects key pathogens like Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae to guide treatment and prevent complications.

Treatment

First-line Therapy:

Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose, or

Cefoxitin 2g IM single dose + Probenecid 1g PO single dose, or

Cefotaxime IV.

Add Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 14 days, with or without Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD for 14 days.

Male Partner Treatment

Treat with Cefixime + Azithromycin (Grey kit in India) to prevent reinfection.

Out-patient Therapy (India)

Yellow kit: Ceftriaxone, Doxycycline, Metronidazole for syndromic management.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 45-year-old woman who is a mother of three, experiencing discomfort and a mass in her lower abdomen? During examination, her uterus appears uniformly enlarged and the adnexa is unaffected. An MRI reveals the presence of a cyst within the uterine muscle.
questions.explanation:
Definition

Presence of endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium, leading to uterine enlargement.

Epidemiology

Common in parous women over 40 years of age.

Clinical Features
  • Abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB).
  • Chronic pelvic pain.
  • Globally enlarged and globular uterus (if diffuse).

Investigations

Primary Investigation: TVS with Color Doppler.

Key Signs on USG:

  • Shutter/Venetian Blind sign (echogenic striations).
  • Central vascularity on Doppler.

Diagnostic Criteria:

  • Asymmetrical uterine wall thickness (posterior > anterior).
  • Heterogeneous myometrial echotexture.
  • Hypoechoic myometrial cysts (honeycomb appearance).
  • Striated projections from endometrium to myometrium.
  • Poorly defined endometrial echo.
  • J-Zone thickening ≥12 mm.

Secondary Investigation: MRI (if USG is inconclusive).

 

  • Thickened junctional zone (>12 mm).
  • High-intensity myometrial foci on T2-weighted images.

Histopathology

Myometrial infiltration by endometrial glands and stroma.

 

Medical Management
  • Combined OCPs and progestin-only regimens (for dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia).
  • NSAIDs (for pain and menorrhagia).
  • LNG-IUS (for menorrhagia).
  • GnRH agonists (for subfertility or pre-surgical symptom relief).
  • Danazol (for menorrhagia and pain).

Surgical Management

Conservative:

  • Adenomyomectomy (risk of recurrence).
  • Uterine mass reduction (laparotomy/laparoscopy).
  • Uterine artery embolization (UAE).

Definitive: Total hysterectomy.

questions.text: Which among the following regions is free from rabies?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C) Lakshadweep

Agent factor
  • Zoonotic disease with a 100% fatality rate
  • Lyssavirus type 1
    • Bullet-shaped RNA virus (Rhabdoviridae family).
  • Two Types of Viruses:
    • Street virus:
      • Cause natural infection (Rabies)
      • Variable incubation period (7 days-months)
    • Fixed virus:
      • Fixed incubation period (5-7 days)
      • For vaccine production.
      • It does not demonstrate Negri bodies.

Host factors
  • Occupation
    • Dog handlers
    • Forest workers
    • Veterinarians.

Transmission
  • Incubation period: 2-8 weeks
  • Animal bite: Dog, Cat, Monkey or Wild animal (all need vaccination)
  • Licks on abraded skin are considered as the route of transmission.
  • Rodent bites don't require vaccination.
  • Human bite is a very dangerous bite (no documented cases yet)
  • In India:
    • Urban Rabies is very common.
    • Rabies is not found around water-bounded areas (Lakshadweep and Andaman and Nicobar Islands) (Option C)

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1L1 presents with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum in labor, and loss of fetal movements. She occasionally smokes but does not consume alcohol or recreational drugs. On examination, her pulse rate is 80 bpm, BP is 150/90 mmHg, and her abdomen is tense on palpation. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Revealed

  • Most common type, where the bleeding from the placental detachment is visible and exits through the vagina.
  • This is often associated with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain.

Concealed

  • Bleeding is hidden behind the placenta and is not visible externally.
  • Blood collects within the uterus, causing increased pressure and pain without visible bleeding.

Mixed

  • Involves both concealed and revealed bleeding.
  • There is both internal and external bleeding, with some blood exiting through the vagina and some collecting behind the placenta.

Grade

Maternal findings

Fetal findings

0
  • Clinical features may be absent.
  • The diagnosis is made after inspection of the placenta following delivery.

1

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness ±)

Fetal heart sounds are normal

2

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness always +)

Fetal distress

3

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain (marked uterine tenderness) + Shock ± Coagulopathy

Fetal death

 

Placenta previa

Abruptio placentae

Clinical features

Nature of bleeding

Painless, causeless, and recurrent.

Painful, often attributed to Pre-eclampsia or trauma, and continuous.

Character of blood

Bleeding is always revealed.

Revealed, concealed, or usually mixed.

General condition & anaemia

Proportionate to visible blood loss.

Out of proportion to the visible blood loss in the concealed or mixed variety.

Features of eclampsia

Not relevant.

Present in one-third of the cases.

Abdominal examination

Height of the uterus

Proportionate height to the gestational age.

It may be disproportionately enlarged in concealed type.

The feel of the uterus

Soft and relaxed.

It may be tense, tender, and rigid.

Malpresentation

Common (the head is high floating).

Unrelated, the head may be engaged.

Fetal heart sounds

Usually present.

Usually absent, especially in the concealed type.

USG, MRI

Placenta in the lower segment.

Placenta in the upper segment.

Vaginal examination

The placenta is felt on the lower segment (not to be done in a suspected case).

The placenta is not felt on the lower segment. Blood clots should not be confused with placenta.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female, married for the past 5 years, presents with complaints of inability to conceive despite regular intercourse. Physical examination is unremarkable. Semen analysis of the husband revealed no abnormalities. Hysterosalpingography reveals the following picture. The anomaly shown in the image below falls under which category of the American Fertility Society classification of Müllerian duct anomalies?
questions.explanation:
Müllerian Duct Anomaly

Description

Clinical Features

Diagnosis

Management

Class I

 

Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) Syndrome

 

(Option D)
  • Complete or partial absence of the uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina.
  • Ovaries are normal.
  • Primary amenorrhea.
  • Absence of menstruation.
  • Normal secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Pelvic ultrasound.
  • MRI.
  • Karyotyping.
  • Vaginal reconstruction.
  • Assisted reproduction for fertility (gestational surrogacy or oocyte donation).

Class II

Unicornuate Uterus
  • Uterus is smaller and only one side develops.
  • Can have a rudimentary horn.
  • Dysmenorrhea.
  • Infertility.
  • Recurrent miscarriage.
  • Ectopic pregnancy.
  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG).
  • MRI.
  • Surgical removal of rudimentary horn.
  • Fertility management.
  • Cesarean delivery in case of pregnancy.

Class III

Bicornuate Uterus

 

(Option B)
  • Uterus has two horns.
  • Often with a deep indentation in the upper part.
  • Single cervix.
  • Menstrual irregularities.
  • Recurrent pregnancy loss.
  • Preterm labor.
  • HSG.
  • MRI.
  • Laparoscopy.
  • Surgical correction (metroplasty) in some cases.
  • Supportive care for pregnancy management.

Class IV

Septate Uterus

 

(Option A)
  • Normally shaped uterus but with a fibrous or muscular septum dividing the cavity.
  • Recurrent miscarriage.
  • Infertility.
  • Preterm labor.
  • HSG.
  • MRI.
  • Sonohysterogram.
  • Laparoscopy.
  • Surgical resection of the septum (hysteroscopic septoplasty).
  • Fertility treatments if needed.

Class V

Arcuate Uterus
  • Mild indentation of the uterine fundus with a normal external uterine contour.
  • Often asymptomatic.
  • May have recurrent miscarriage.
  • Preterm birth.
  • HSG.
  • MRI.
  • Typically no treatment required.
  • Management of complications like miscarriage may be necessary.

Class VI

Didelphys Uterus

 
  • Complete non-fusion of the Müllerian ducts.
  • Two separate uterine cavities and cervices.
  • Vaginal septum.
  • Recurrent miscarriage.
  • Preterm labor.
  • Infertility.
  • HSG.
  • MRI.
  • Laparoscopy.
  • Surgical correction if needed.
  • Assisted reproductive techniques (ART) for infertility.

  • Thumb sign( On folding thumb, it will protrude beyond the ulnar border of palm) or wrist sign is positive
  • Increased joint laxity

CVS abnormalities:
  • Aortic root dilation
  • Mitral insufficiencies
  • Arrhythmias

Eye abnormalities:
  • Ectopia lentis or subluxation of the lens of the eye (Option D)
  • Blindness

Pulmonary involvement:

  • Increased risk of pneumothorax

questions.text: What is considered the most reliable tonometer in the medical field?
What is the main underlying factor responsible for regular astigmatism when studying the optics of a patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Abnormal curvature of the cornea
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Abnormal curvature of the cornea

Type

Description

With-the-Rule (WTR)

The vertical meridian has greater curvature than the horizontal meridian.

Against-the-Rule (ATR)

The horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian.

Oblique Astigmatism

Principal meridians are at oblique angles (e.g., 45° and 135°), still perpendicular to each other.

Bi-oblique Astigmatism

Principal meridians are not perpendicular to each other (e.g., 30° and 100°).

Type

Description

Simple Astigmatism

One meridian focuses on the retina; the other focuses in front (simple myopic) or behind (simple hypermetropic).

Compound Astigmatism

Both meridians focus light either in front (compound myopic) or behind (compound hypermetropic) the retina.

Mixed Astigmatism

One meridian focuses in front of the retina (myopic), and the other behind (hypermetropic).

questions.text: What is the term used to describe a disease that is typically not found in a country but is brought in from abroad, as seen in the case of a 25-year-old male who was diagnosed with the condition upon arrival at an Indian airport, leading to quarantine?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D) Exotic

Term

Definition

Examples

Epidemic (Option B ruled out)
  • Occurrence of disease clearly in excess of normal expectancy (Mean + 2SD or >80% expected frequency).
  • Occurrence of even a single case of a previously eliminated disease.
  • Occurrence of a single case of an exotic disease. (Option D)

Seasonal influenza outbreaks during winter months.

Endemic (Option A ruled out)

 
  • Constant presence of a disease within a specific population.
  • Epidemiologically linked cases in terms of time, place, or person.

Malaria in Africa, TB in India

Pandemic
  • Global spread of a disease.
  • Defined as an epidemic in a large population.
  • Requires crossing 2 continents and 2 WHO-specific regions.

HIV/AIDS, COVID-19.

Sporadic
  • They occur randomly and unpredictably, without any discernible pattern in time, location, or individual.
  • There's no epidemiological link between the cases.

Tetanus

questions.text: Installation and usage of sanitary latrines by general public constitutes which level of prevention:
questions.explanation:
Level of Prevention

Goals

Examples

Primordial

To prevent the establishment of risk factors

  • Lifestyle modification
  • Health promotion

Primary

Interventions to prevent the onset of disease
  • Vaccinations
  • Health education
  • Family planning
  • Use of mosquito nets
  • Pre-placement examinatio

Secondary

Early detection and prompt treatment of disease to prevent complications (Option C ruled out)
  • Screening tests (e.g., mammograms, PAP smears)
  • Self-examinations
  • Health camps with screening DOTS for TB; ART for HIV; MDT for leprosy.

Tertiary

Interventions to manage and reduce complications of existing disease to prevent disability or death (Option D ruled out)
  • Rehabilitation
  • Physical therapy
  • Chronic disease management programs
  • Reconstructive surgery
